description:
You can get a shot and a Tecate for five bones, which is pretty great for this side of the Bay. Why have one of a thing when you can have two? By now I've convinced myself that Dickel tastes great, though really, anything tastes good if you wash it down with some Tecate, including spite and sadness. Those are the two key active ingredients in Dickel, right? 

There's also a sort of smoker's isolation tank where you can hang out with a beat-up piano that someone probably bought at Tom Waits's garage sale.

Like some sort of grubby, evil TARDIS, Edinburgh looks really tiny on the outside and is secretly gigantic on the inside. It's pretty dark, too, which I count as a plus because I don't think light would be flattering to either the bar or its patrons (i.e. me). Don't get it twisted; it only LOOKS like the kind of place where people break pool cues over their knees in futile attempts to defeat Patrick Swayze. It's been super-chill every time I've been there. Which is usually on a Monday, for some reason. 

Staff's great, too.
author: Jim M.

description:
If you're in the mood for a cheap pint in a place that smells like thick piss, look no further than Edinburgh Castle Pub. 

I came in twice on a Saturday night because my idiot friend forgot his credit card. The place was nearly empty and somehow the classic San Francisco smell of Tenderloin streets was stronger inside the bar than out. I'm actually shocked to now find out that they apparently serve food here? 

I'm not going to advise anyone against eating here but I will present you with the knowledge of the women's restroom, that has 2 stalls. One of which has a toilet that does not flush and a door that once locked, jams. So be prepared to go full Kool Aid Man to get out there like I had to. When you go to wash your hands you'll notice there's not only no soap, but the sink is not even hooked up to water. I have no idea how many women work here, but they aren't washing their hands up in this piece. 

I went back to my friend at the bar who was truly disgusted that I came back with "piss hands" even though I'm 70% sure I did not pee on my hands. But I guess I see his point. 

The great thing about this place is that on a pretty prime Saturday evening in a bar that could probably hold 250 people, there were maybe 11 people here in total and that includes the bartended, my friend, and I . So there were plenty of seats, it had a great dive bar vibe, the accompanying SF dive bar smell, and while you maybe need to bring your own hand sanitizer, it's a cool gritty place to come with a big group for maybe the cheapest drinks in town.
author: Candice G.

description:
Probably as close to trad fish and chips as I'm gonna get in this town! That being said, the whole fry option (where you get a bit of everything) always seems a little overpriced. Does it? Maybe I've gotten greedy. You do get a piece of fish, chips, onion rings, battered prawns, and some other bits... which now I recount all that I'm sure it's more me being a glutton than it being a particularly small portion. 

In any case, those chips and that fish are delish. Plus, the guy that often serves us is so so lovely.

Love the vibe -- pool table, great juke box, and booths. Love little side room to hang out in. Last time one of the local DJs set up to practice in there and it was awesome. He plays on Thursdays, apparently, so I'll be back for that!

Drinks are cheap enough and it always seems relaxed on week days. I'm sure it gets a bit more lively over the weekend, but I've yet to stop in then. Big fan!
author: Rowena H.

description: If a girl, your homie lover or friend gets punched in the face just know NO ONE  (INCLUDING ALL EMPLOYEES) won't give a damn and won't do anything about it except look at you like a deer Infront of headlights. PATHETIC ASS STAFF
author: Marisa C.

description: Randa the bartender gave us excellent service! She got a huge rush but still made sure She took care of everyone! If I ever come back to San Fran I will be back to see her for sure!! Thank you again for the great service!
author: Jasmine B.

description:
Went here for the tuesday trivia night. We got a couple $15-18 pitchers of beer (evil twin, dragon slayer,  blue moon, etc etc) which is a great deal! The bartender also gave us small taster glasses because we were debating on our first pitcher, which was nice! 

There were roughly 20-30 people there (8:30-10PM), and our team ("in dog drinks we've only had one") got flattened in the trivia. Like, who comes up with these questions and why do people know these answers. 

If you put it on google maps, it might tell you to go to cedar road and not Geary. The entrance on cedar road is super sketchy and empty and difficult to find. Go to the entrance on Geary that is much more legit and noticeable. The bathroom sort of looks like a scene from a horror movie, but has character, I guess. 

I had just come from a dance class and hadn't eaten dinner so I was really excited for bar food. They sell fish and chips, onion rings, fried prawns and oysters. Fish was soggy, fries and onion rings were meh, and the prawns/oysters were fine. Pro tip would probably be to just order the drinks here.
author: Grace P.

description:
Ok, ok upon first entering the bar- it sorta looks dumpy. But wouldn't a true Scottish pub be older and worn down? It adds to authenticity!

Pool tables, seating for those not looking to mix and mingle, very spacious- two stories, full bar and friendly bartenders. The style and decor made us feel like we stumbled into a European Bar. 

So much fun that one of the members of our party (from Sacramento) is planning to enjoy his next birthday here. 

Can't wait to come back!
author: Tracy M.

description:
I like this place because it is how I imagined all bars to look when I was a kid. Double swinging doors inside the metal gated entryway, and a dim red-orange glow cast over the whole thing. A lot of places like Edinburgh haven't survived the barrage of evictions and takeovers, but it has managed to stick around in all of its worn-in ways.

This place can get crazy, and it can also be totally desolate at times, but I find it enjoyable in just about any shape. Dartboard and pool table, a cozy tap list and a solid bar with plenty of seats. Unpretentious and looking like it was carved out of the building it inhabits - I can't ask for much more.

Atmosphere: Bigger than you'd expect. Nice little seating areas on the second level above the bar. Large smoking area in the front, closed off from the main area.

Try: A nice little fish & chips kitchen in the back, so you can get some solid bar food while you're there
author: Taylor S.

description:
Candy Rain!!!!!!!!!!! 

Only reason to come here tbh. They play the best music (think 90s/00s/10s hip hop & R&B) on the first and third Saturday of the month. Any other time I've come here the ambiance is cool but the music is super whatever. I now know when to come back! Thanks, Edinburgh for putting me on to one of the dopest DJs around!
author: Kayla M.

description: Very good beer here!!! Had the death & taxes beer... Awesome!!!! Very cool ambiance just a little divey. Very cool tender socializing with... About beer, sports etc
author: Rich M.

description: I can't believe some of the reviews on here for four and five stars. You all must be stoned or high on something. This place is dirty, dingy and the table tops are sticky. Giving them three stars for a fun Trivia Host and for our beautiful server. I did love that they had the Giants game on the tv and then switched to TCM when it was all over, it added to the ambiance a little bit as it was an old 40's movie that was playing.  Fun for trivia night definitely check that out, the drinks compared to some of the bars in San Diego are very reasonably priced. Wines all night for 5.00 and the beer was a good price too.  We had fun at trivia with the clientele there, everyone was really friendly.  Beware of the neighborhood, it's in the "Ten" so I saw some sketchy sh*t going on when we left at 11:00 pm but you know, the same could be said of some of the bars 2 miles from my house so there's that, I live in a bigger City too. Anyhow to be safe just get out before it gets too late and you won't have any issues, we caught an Uber back to where we were staying, I just didn't feel safe walking around there after midnight.
author: Patricia Patti P W.

description:
When considering reviewing Edinburgh, I honestly didn't know what to say about the venue itself. Though my friends and I had such a fun time and I had just been there the weekend before to encounter tons of foreigners who bought me plenty of Fernet and cokes, which was cool in and of itself, but still, nothing really came to mind that made this drinking experience different than any other. But then I decided, maybe there was something awesome about Edinburgh.

We pranced over after checking out a couple places in NoPa to discover that the bouncer wouldn't accept my friend's passport as her ID. We started to get sad, but then he said he was just kidding! Oh man, this guy's got jokes. Next, we walked in to find that there was a $10 per person cover charge. Sadness reinitiated, as paying covers suck and we only had $6 between the three of us. But then, lo and behold, this bouncer accepted our $6 offering and let all three of us in! Childbearing, periods, and lower pay aside, being a woman has it's perks.

Heading inside we approached the bar, ordered three beers and went up to the top level to look down over the fake rooftop awnings above the main floor. It's such a cute and fun atmosphere, you have to be a real beezy to not at keast enjoy that.

The night continued, hip hop came on, and the drunken white girl in me had to make an appearance. Enter the first bouncer who gave us good natured grief about the passport, commence grinding / dancing / actin' a fool, but who cares it was so fun and he didn't seem to mind. 

As we walked down to the main floor for another bevvy, my friend reached into her purse and pulled out a pair of those funky false hill billy teeth, so naturally I put them in and started dancing more. I, and anyone who came within one foot of me, could not keep a straight face. Yes, we were all surely tispy and reading this you may think I'm an attention whore (which I am), but it was hilarious. 

All in all, an awesome night. Cheap drinks, great music, entertaining staff. One of my favorite TL bars and not too many pretentious hipsters, so that's a major plus.
author: Crystal C.

description: This place is a dump, and I mean that in the most loving way possible. Lots of space. Good drinks and a good price. They serve good food during the day. I'm not sure if the grill operates at night. The bathrooms are lit with a red light and are pretty run down. It totally has a dive bar meets Scottish pub vibe to it (well, that's because that's exactly what it is). If that idea sounds good to you then you will love this place.
author: Brittany W.

description: I don't know what the drinks are like or if the food taste good, but if you happen to walk in here on nights they play hip-hop (apparently the first and third Sat)  you will not be disappointed. I stumbled in (obvi drunk and not aware) and it felt like a music video set for the Hyphy movement. Hip-hop only, ppl wildin' out, and the speakers made you feel like your heart beats to bass. The crowd is young but if you're there to dance...who fcking cares, right?
author: Pawanpreet G.

description:
If you are looking for a Hip hop bar. I know there are few ones left this isn't too bad.  $6 cover is ok seems the place should be free but i guess this keeps out some of the homeless in the area.

I don't like how the bar accepted card and after 10:30 became cash only.

Indoor smoking area.  Cool I don't smoke but cool.

Gets pretty crowded.  Be ready to be shoulder to should on a sat night.
author: Justin I.

description:
The gist: Cool lay-out for booth seating and cool decor, can bring outside food, but the beers are regular prices.

The bar is worth visiting because of the cool interior shingles and nice little booths. Not a great place for a big sit-down group - we had a party-like group in the back that had reserved the big table, and it 1) only fit 6 people and 2) was in between the darts and the pool table, leading to constant power struggle and detente btw the 3 

If you're looking for a fairly quiet bar with booth-seating, it's worth checking out. Walking back down Geary, I saw so many way fancy bars and was glad that we'd gone to such a casual laidback place. Sure, beers and wells were $5-6, which is totally standard on a Saturday, but not something to write home about. I was there until 9 or so on Saturday night and it never got uncomfortably crowded in those evening hours, unless you were between the pool and Darts. 

They only seemed to serve bar eats and Fish and Chips, but the outside food options were pretty good. Lots of Vietnamese and Thai, some cheap pizza.
author: Ari F.

description:
When I used to hear about Edinburgh Castle before I visited for the first time, I actually thought there was a historical castle in SF that people visited. Unfortunately this Edinburgh is far from a castle. 

I enjoy their Tuesday (pretty sure it's Tuesday) trivia night but be warned that the questions are hard and that the wildcard category is particularly random. You can bring food in to enjoy while you share pitchers of beers with your teammates or order cocktails.

I've been a couple times on the weekend and don't enjoy it as much. It gets packed and once time they even charged us $4 cover without a live band. We're still not sure why there was cover that night for a divey bar with a DJ.

A few other random facts - they have a pool tabel, the women's bathroom smells like a dirty fish tank (and doesn't look a whole lot better), there is a neat balcony area up above the main bar area, and I'm pretty sure there are darts also in the front room.
author: Meghan P.

description: All of our friends were pick pocketed here and the security refused to do anything. I see from other reviews that this happens regularly. Beware
author: Melanie M.

description:
I've been here a few times and it's alright. Very young, very crowded, very dingy inside. I think people flock here because it's large, plays hip hop and has cheapish drinks. 

I also live across the street and I see the madness that happens here every single week. Serious fights (someone got knocked out and another guy began stomping...leaping and stomping on his head while he was down), people trying to break into cars for the hell of it, theft. Plus, I always see drunk guys going home with tranny hookers all the time. So if you do choose to go here, have your wits about you and leave before last call because s*** will get crazy.
author: Nic V.

description:
After a few drinks and the onset of a desire to dance the night away, I asked my friend about a vague memory I had of a dive bar paying indie music a few years back when I visited SF.

After what seemed like walking for forever from Mina 111 to the bar my friend thought I was talking about, we ended up at the Edinburgh. It was indeed the bar I was hoping to find.

Reasonable priced drinks and 2 DJs having a 60s and 70s spin off - dream bar!

There's a fair bit of seating, also enough room to throw down some shapes on the dance-floor with seriously injuring anyone.

Pizza store conveniently located outside for eats after the bar closes. A perfect evening!
author: Laura D.

description:
Ok for a beer, nothing special happening here, crowd was seedy tho  :-O 
Perhaps I'll come visit on a different night...
author: Gloria H.

description:
Oh man, do I have some mixed feelings about this place, or what. 

Part of me loves it: it's divey, cheap, a pretty large space for SF, the staff was nice (for the most part), and they were playing some old hip hop last time I was there. I will jam to No Diggity any day of the week (no doubt!)

The part of me that hates it...well, it's in the TL, so you have to politely decline offers for crack or sexual "favors" from tranny hookers on your way to the door (or accept those offers, I don't know your life; no judgments here). There was a $10 cover on a Saturday night which I think is lame sauce. The place was suuuuuuper crowded, in an uncomfortable, "I'm in the middle of a sweaty concert crowd" kinda way. Even that wouldn't be SO bad if the crowd wasn't full of groping fiends. Come on, bros! Me squeezing by you in a crowded bar so I can make my way to the toilets is not an invitation to touch my heiny! But that's the kinda crowd that frequents this place on a weekend evening, I guess.

There's also a patio (?) area for smoking but that smoke smell does not remain in that area. If you're sitting near the door to the smoking area, be prepared to get your daily dose of second-hand smoke. Pretty disgusting for a non-smoker like me.

All in all, the place has potential, but it's never my first choice when I'm looking for some weekend drinks.
author: Stephenie S.

description:
I want to love this bar I really do. 

I've been here several times. Good drinks, good music. The general lay out of the bar is pretty good too. You have a wide dance floor on the first floor, a balcony seating area on the second and an indoor/outdoor smoking patio. Really nifty set up. You can easily get into the party or just chill out upstairs if you want to relax. 

That having been said, the amount of hippster/emo smug in this place is over-whelming. There's quite a bit. I usually try to avoid these types of places but the damn music is too good. I just don't get the whole scene, in attempting to be unique you're being just like everyone else. Grow up. 

Also the bar staff is not friendly. My buddy left a two dollar tip on one drink and a bar man said "go fuck yourself". At the right bar that would be humorous but in a loud club when the guy says it under his breath failing to make eye contact, it's just bitchy. 

If the bartenders smile I'd give this place 4 stars. If they'd improve their beer selection I'd give this place 5 stars. I can handle the hippsters, that's more of a personal vendetta.
author: Jared P.

description:
This is what I think when I think dive bar. If I am going to go to a place that feels run down and old and has an irresistible charm nonetheless I want that charm to be authentic not created in a focus group and processed with a dive bar coating. I want weird things hanging from the walls you can't explain, I want old wood everywhere and smells you can't explain. I want odd bartenders and even odder patrons and I want pool, a juke box, and food that probably shouldn't be served from a bar. Check to all those things and more.

Edinburgh Castle is a no frills dive bar that has feels like a pub you would find somewhere in Scotland or London. I have gone on trivia nights on Tuesday which I would recommend to everyone. The host is funny and doesn't take the game too serious but actually runs a really great game. The bartender I have had is always this kind of surly older gentleman but he will get to you eventually. The beers are super cheap as you would expect as well, especially on tap. 

The area around Edinburgh isn't the greatest but people who don't look like tourists or don't have their money and cellphones dangling about in their hands really won't ever have a problem. Its the secret those of us near the tenderloin keep to ourselves. There are actually some really great places over here and if the yuppies are too scared to venture here because of what they heard about an area then its all the better for us. 

I haven't been there for the apparently packed Friday and Saturdays but there is always room to meet up with friends or grab a seat at the bar when I have been here. This is the only place that I feel like uncanny ability to remember which guy was the guy in that one movie is a skill worth having.
author: Nick R.

description: Awesome selection of beers on draft and that too for super cheap. Interior is super divey and bartenders are fun to talk to
author: Ami D.

description: Kind of a young rowdy crowd but they have great hip hop music..stiff drinks are always a plus esp when they come at a fair rate..
author: Sean R.

description:
PLEASE NEVER EVER EVER EVER GO HERE. Our group had 3 phones, 1 wallet and one camera stolen from our purses that were on us the whole time. They do not crowd control at all so the place ends up getting way too busy- which then results in people being able to pick pocket easily. I understand that the people of Edinburgh Castle were not aware of the pick pocketers at the time, but when I called the next day to explain and check in on my wallet they acted annoyed and extremely unapologetic. 

As we told the employees of Edinburgh that night, they really should have lockers or some type of coat check to make sure this type of thing doesn't happen again.
author: Elle G.

description: Awesome dive but with class.  Great selection of brews! Say hey to the owner Tay. Great history!
author: Mike R.

description: Expect the unexpected. Visited on a Saturday night and the place was poppin! The name implies English pub but wait until you get inside. The DJ was blasting every great rap song from Wu Tang to the present and a projector was playing Boys in the Hood on the back wall. People of all trends and lifestyles were dancing together and the vibe reminded me of the perfect house party. I loved every minute of it. The only downer is the bar is cash only which really blows but on the upside the bartenders don't really measure out the drinks so the result is some seriously strong cocktails. Cheers!
author: Stephanie P.

description:
What's not to like if you're kicking off a night that will inevitably escalate to booty dancing and intense, loud sidewalk conversations? Besides the insane surfable crowd that accumulates on the weekends, this place as it all. 

Seating, full bar, friendly staff, pool tables, and at least when I'm there, they pump that dirty dance hip hop at the epitome of everyone's sloppiness. Lil Jon knows when he is needed, and you always go to the window and to the wall like the drunk little lemming you are.
author: Chelsea B.

description:
Came in before 10pm and it was still pretty empty, so we were able to find a booth easily. A waitress approached us and asked us if we wanted drinks. We paid her and she pretty much asked for a tip, using the "lack" of change she had on hand as an excuse. Girl, I will tip you maybe after my second drink and after I feel like I've had a good time, especially if you helped with that. But nonetheless, you shouldn't be asking for tips anyways. The cocktails we got tasted watered down, and lacked alcohol. I went up to the bar to speak to one of the male bartenders, and it was obvious he wasn't pleased to hear me asking him to fix my drink. He eventually gave me a different drink later, but the overall customer service I received here was lacking. None of the bartenders were smiling, nor looked like they wanted to be there. After my friend tipped one of the bartenders (and her drink wasn't even that good), she didn't smile nor say thank you.

We came on a Friday night, so it was Hip Hop night, but only the first hour and a half featured throwbacks and classics. The rest of the night felt like a lot of Drake. Before the hip hop, they played Jingle Bells (?!) and it's the beginning of September. Not impressed by this place, and am glad I came early enough before the $10 cover charge started.
author: Kristine N.

description: This place is a really great dive bar.  I wish I could take it home with me.  The surrounding area is not the greatest, but it's worth it.
author: Matthew V.

description: I hate to give a bad review but I hope to prevent someone else from wasting their money.  We looked up this place and after reading other reviews we walked the couple blocks to give it a try.  We LOVE hole in the wall pubs and thought we found a little secret in this one but after ordering a vodka energy I had serious doubts.  It tasted like pure energy and no vodka.  I ordered a Long Island..$13!!!  It was the sweetest and worst drink I've ever had.  If you go here order beer...only beer.  You will get ripped off ordering cocktails.
author: Nic M.

description: Drinks and beer menu were fine, and priced appropriately for the neighborhood. DO NOT ORDER FOOD. The fish and chips are cooked at a Korean restaurant and delivered. More like boiled in oil than fried. It was Sunday and the atmosphere was really slow with 4 people there. I would never come back for the food. I wish the bartender had told me the food isn't very good. It's worth noting he didn't bother asking how it was.
author: Adelore L.

description:
This place used to be the shit!.....

:/

A good few years ago.

Now-its just an obnoxious hipster dive with too many underage "holier than thou" preying lads and laddies. 

Not for me. Not tonight.
author: Anna G.

description:
Ermahgerd.  I love this place.

Look, it's divey as hell.  So if you want to take a girl somewhere and impress them -- this is NOT it.  That being said, if you want to let loose and kick back a few brews, this is the spot.  It's got a pool table and darts, and occasionally a dj.

The bartenders here are fantastic.  Very attentive and all up for a bit of banter.

The bathrooms smell of rancid piss, but you know what.  I wouldn't change it if I could.  It just reminds you that you aren't drunk enough yet.  It's an assault on your sobriety, which frankly, is the enemy of Edinburgh Castle Pub.  This is one of those places that doesn't really make sense until you've had a few.  You know what I mean -- You come in sober and check the place, and wonder how anyone could tolerate it.  5 pints later, HOLY CRAP THIS IS GREAT!

Also -- their fish and chips are going to make you fat, but don't worry about that.  They are DELICIOUS!  Just do it.  Fish and chips and a boddingtons -- and you'll be a new man.  You'll have wandered in from the fog and the grit -- thinking yourself in a rougher part of scotland, and voila, it'll all make sense as you douse your fish and chips with vinegar.  Don't use ketchup, you pillac!  MALT VINEGAR, do you speak it?!

That's all there is to say about that really.  The best authentic pub I've found in the city.  Come here and get twisted.
author: Yan L.

description:
Edinburgh will always be remembered as the place where my friend discovered she loved Blue Moon beer (it wasn't in Australia at the time) and the time I got so drunk I started a d&m with the pool table. 
Three stars for the older guy who told us about the 'after 2am' scene. If only I had remembered what they were.
author: Angel W.

description:
For about 10 years I've been coming to the Castle, largely, because it's the same place that it was 10, 20, probably 30 years ago.  Here are some fun facts:

Film crews used a snow machine to make it look wintery when filming So I Married an Axe Murderer. 

Back in the day, underage drinkers could sneak in through from the filthy alley entrance.  Now closed off.

There's an attic where bands used to play.  The sound was terrible, it was a fire hazard, but many remember it as being The Most Awesome Thing Ever.

The jukebox has always been one of the best in the city.  David Bowie, T Rex, Pulp, you know.

Every other Wednesday is "1964."  It gets packed with hip kids in tight pants, dancing to old 45's.   It used to be a simple affair but now the line can go down the street, so come early if you want to get in.

Tuesday night trivia is one of the best in town, and can get VERY competitive.  

Happy hour goes until 8pm!  2 pieces fish & chips and ANY pint for $10.  Shot of well and a PBR for 5.  

There's usually one tv playing a ball game and one tuned to AMC.  The other night I sat at the bar and watched Predator 2 almost in its entirety.

You can smoke in the tap room in front.  If you step in for 30 seconds on crowded nights, everything on your person will smell like an ash tray forever.
author: Ryan P.

description:
Man did you see the size of that pub!?!

This place is huge and deep.  Was kinda difficult for me to find it. 

 I think its pretty cool they allow food in there..or at least the pizza place next door.  

It felt a bit too dark but then again it IS a pub.  I didnt order any drinks but I had a great time here, perhaps more because of the company. :]
author: Tu-Anh N.

description: Uh... It's closed on St. Patricks day?! We were creating our own make shift (free) pub crawl... And it's all boarded up and closed! Booooo! We ended up across the street at Amsterdam cafe...
author: Liz M.

description:
Usually the bars I wander into in the city are a bit over priced, but the Edinburgh Castle Pub had great prices on both the drinks and the beer!  Plus their happy hour goes till 8pm! Smart! 

They've got a nice long bar, tons of tables, and plenty of room in between. Pool table, jukebox, and even a smoking lounge complete with piano!

The fish and chips smelled really gooood, but I didn't get to have any as we were only here to kill time before meeting up with some friends for dinner.. 

Funny, as I'm typing up this review, I see several of my fellow Sacramento Yelpers have also enjoyed this pub!
author: Jeremy W.

description: This is a dive bar, yes. It is also pretty rad. Beware of the influx of people that will pour in around midnight. It gets pretty crazy-busy (I'm talking no room to move and fighting to keep a seat). The drinks are strong, decent and cheap (score) and there are plenty of distractions to be found. They have trivia nights, pool tables, DJ's of questionable talent, as well as an over-priced jukebox that can pull up any song your intoxicated arse can dream up. The best part about this bar is that there are cool bartenders (shout out to Alan) and most of the people you run into aren't total douchebags. There is also cheap pizza next door if you want to sober up a bit before you head home. Overall, a good place. It would be better if they had live music, but apparently the fire department shut that down :-/
author: Melissa T.

description:
Really liked this place reminds of the lego movie saloon only skinner
Friendly staff ...fish n chips!!! 
Love it
author: D W.

description: Horrible service, and the bar tender was rude as well. Our food never came, and the server cussed us out because she swore that she brought us our drinks, and NEVER DID! This place needs to evaluate their staff on customer service, and manners! I'll never go back, and I'll be sure to spread word of mouth about my awful experience. Stay classy.
author: Vee M.

description:
Came here for drinks a few weeks ago before heading out for supper. Since it was early (6'ish), the place was pretty empty. The bartender was super friendly and nice and got us our drinks quick. 

Not a bad place if your'e stopping by for a beer or cider.
author: Cassandra J.

description:
I found this place on accident while in San Francisco.  I'm not entirely sure why this place reminded me of home, but I guess the feel of the bar reminded me of those I frequent in Chicago.  Dark, good beer, hipsters....except these hipsters are nicer than the ones in Chicago.  

I ended up at a table with a decently large group of people and the waitress was great.  I'm seriously surprised she came through as often as she did, even when it got crowded.  Never ate my corn dog (I'm not even sure why I ordered it) but the fish & chips hit the spot.  I don't remember the price of beer, but I definitely though it was fair.
author: Claudia S.

description:
When people ask me what my favorite bars in SF are, I don't really know how to answer; nothing springs to my mind. However, when I'm at Edinburgh, I always enjoy myself, which I guess is what counts, right?

Edinburgh is home to a couple great club nights (1964, Nightbeat), but even on off nights, it's a fun place to grab a couple pints. There are plenty of seats at the long bar, booths, and upstairs (if they have it open.) I always hear how back in the day, they held 1964 in the now closed room upstairs (and curse the fact that I couldn't see that at least once.) Also has a dedicated smoking space up in the front, which is often as packed as the rest of the bar.

The bathrooms are pretty disgusting, thankfully I don't need to spend too much time in there nor actually touch any of the fixtures. But I guess it's kind of fitting for the ambiance of the bar to have dirty restrooms. Reminds me of the 'worst toilet in scotland' scene from Trainspotting.

Can't forget to mention there are also bartenders walking around taking orders for more drinks. What's better than being able to get more beer without having to lose your seat and/or squeeze in between people at the bar?

Definitely a must if you're in the TL.
author: Jon T.

description:
I have very mixed feelings about this bar after 10 years of visiting it. To be fair, I go once or twice a year when I visit San Francisco, usually in December. The environment is great, there's a good beer and whiskey selection, and the prices are reasonable though not surprising given the required transit through the Demilitarized Zone known colloquially as "the Tenderloin".

The following rant is directed mostly at Captain Sullen Sullenberger aka The Dyspeptic Scottish Barkeep (hereafter S.S.). When I order a drink from this guy, I get treated like the person who (presumably) ran over his dog (repeatedly). At this point, I wish I had. Sullen is the middle aged male bartender (owner?) who over the years has become an enormous poopy pants. To be fair the static-emanating music system, which almost blue-screened my frontal lobe, can give him a run for his money. (Just between us, neighborhood bars in the Tenderloin don't need club music even if the hipsters claim otherwise.) I guess if S.S. really is the owner, game over man, game over!

Seriously though, I don't need to be screamed at "There's nothing free here!" and glared at like Dick Cheney in a peyote-fueled drum circle as I take a tonic water that had been served twice to me for free earlier in the night by the much more pleasant Happy-Hour shift barkeep. He had even said "cheers!"

In previous years S.S. has been "chode-like" aka dickish about ejecting people playing games on the upper level at the end of the night, ruder than other bartenders I have interacted with in similar situations. Perhaps I'm old fashioned, but I don't think it's unreasonable to take 2 extra mins to finish a pool game. I also don't think it's a paradigm shift to treat your customers with some basic respect. When I return the following year and he's still there, I know the same thing will happen. Last night was the final straw. I will throw my lot in with the Irish Bank, Owl Tree, or some other haunt much closer to the AGU epicenter.
author: Andy F.

description:
Amazing dive bar experience in San francisco.

was filled wtih cool people and great music. cheap drinks and that feeling of artistic liberation only san francisco can offer. it's the crowd that makes such bars classic institutions
author: Oculus C.

description:
I sang Katy Perry's "Hot n Cold" here once, for a school function. And it was awesome. 


But OH! THE CHIPS! THE CHIPPPPSSSS (get the chips!)
author: Emily D.

description:
HA! Recently discovered this place, and I actually like it a lot.

I didn't find the crowd here to be as douchey as Polk. The ambiance was kinda cool..."castle" themed haha. Drink specials were cool. I think they had good beers on tap? Who knows... I went there in a drunken stupor. 

All in all, it's a pretty spacious bar for a casual weeknight gathering. Seems like a locals spot for sure.
author: Paul B.

description:
Seems like a random dive bar when you get to the door.

Then you walk in and.. still a dive bar. But a really nice spacious one w/ an upstairs seating area.

Almost looks like a barn.. a nice lively barn that serves good drinks. My friends and I almost felt like square dancing. Not really.

Overall nice chill spot.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
Gone are the days when debauchery at Edinburgh Castle was enhanced by a newspaper-wrapped bundle of grease-tacular fish 'n' chips from the shop around the corner. Gone, but not forgotten. 

However, despite the fact that the secret's out on this place, and it's often packed with hip regulars on weekends, fun is almost always a certainty at the Castle. 

Check the calendar for legendary Trivia nights, and look for the occasional soul DJ on Wednesdays. The soul nights are the jam.
author: Christina S.

description: Mellow place. Nothing too spectacular. Typical dive. Had a stiff drink here....bartender makes strong pours. DJ was alright. Ladies' room was clean. Might come back if I was in the the hood.
author: Liv A.

description: Bomb classic. If youre smart enough,  they have the best trivia ever, tues? I think. Boddingtons on draft and it smells like a true pub.
author: Lenny K.

description:
This is probably one of the biggest bars in San Francisco, and it had some fun music and dancing. In terms of demographics, I think it's mostly partiers from the Polk Gulch that wandered a little too far into the TL.

One reason I'm hesitant to go back is the smell. There is a smoker's lounge in the front of the bar, and the scent definitely wafts back into the regular area. But besides that, there was also a very distinct vomit/urine smell that permeated the whole place. I want to give them the benefit of the doubt and say it was just one of those nights, but I'm not sure it's worth going back to find out.
author: Lindsay S.

description:
Good selection of beers. Good trivia, and good fish and chips. The menu is limited beyond a couple other side items. The frying is light, relative to traditional seafood frying, but not light by SF dietary standards. 

Trivia is good, and the host is interesting, but the rewards definitely aren't generous from my experience in other parts of the country.
author: Mike H.

description: Went here on Valentines with a group and there were only 5 other people in here. It was my first time and I was surprised to find any place so popular with so little people but once the clock striked 11 people filled in quite rapidly.  This bar is divey but in all the right ways. Good older music, strong drinks, pool table and great grungy without being dirty vibe!
author: Brittini S.

description:
Ahhh home at ye olde castle.

Edinburgh Castle is practically a San Francisco institution.  Chances are you've ended up here at least once before you even knew where or what the Tenderloin was and before you knew beers better than Newcastle or Boddy's.  You've done the requisite cab battle outside and probably didn't even know there was an upstairs.  

In any case I usually find this a great multi-purpose bar.  It's close enough to downtown that it's a decent meeting point for visitors yet you've ended up here on random weekend nights with your friends so it's a bit of a locals place too.  The seats can be cramped but that all makes for a more intimate feeling.  It's relatively neat but with that layer of grime so it feels like it might be a dive.  The beer selection isn't the greatest though they do have a good range of the United Kingdom's finest offerings.  The Black Prince Porter is a welcome selection if you're looking for something dark and have long ago divorced Guinness.  The trivia night is solid and a good outing.  You know you won't win anyway and the questions are decently difficult that you can give your cognitive acumen a good workout while killing brain cells.

Probably the biggest gripe is the food.  Everyone seems to tout the fish and chips but I found them sub-average at best.  The breading was too soggy and soft and it seemed to not only dwarf the fish but also ruin the flavor of the veggies.  Just like any other bar you really enjoy it becomes a quasi hipster colony on the weekends and competition for a cab after last call could be an Olympic event but weekday nights or three day weekend Sundays are still great.

Despite the selectivity required in visiting, I'll still look forward to visiting the Castle.
author: Steven R.

description:
I'm grateful that Friday night I did not have to pay a $10 cover charge. Friend wanted to relive his long-lost college days. It's been a long time since I've sat on brawl proof  furniture. One hopes there is a vermin eradication system.

Given the always upward trending price points of San Francisco, I really wonder how this establishment survives. While I personally probably will not return, I think it is a place that should remain for the sake of diversity alone. Because if the city only caters to the posh and polished, certainly we will have lost something.
author: Karen R.

description:
People insist on giving other folks labels. Whether you're 'punk' or 'emo', 'rockabilliy',  'new age Amish' or anything else. I personally don't like the idea of fitting into one random group, so I'm generally unamused when people say I'm a hipster.

To those that label me so, I laugh at thee. If I'm such a hipster why don't I just loooooove Edinburgh like all the rest of the hipster flock? As of right now, 47 of the 340 reviews of the Castle mention hipsters taking over this place, and yea, I'm not that impressed. Take THAT people that call me a hipster.

Now there's nothing wrong being a hipster and there's nothing wrong three stars either. I find the place to be pretty solid, the usual makeup for a decent pub: jukebox, pool, lots'o'beer.

I think Edinburgh has a nice setup too with booths, tables, dim lighting, and a long bar. I dig the tall ceiling giving it a very open feel. I guess I'm just not amazed to the point of seeking this place out consistently. Been here on a few Friday/Saturday nights, had some beer and whiskey, the purpose was served.

I'll probably be back, and you know, maybe some day I'll fall in love with Edinburgh. If you see a 5 star update from me it's likely I went and met some hot hipster chicks which will drastically alter my opinion. There I go labeling 'hot hipster chicks' all hypocritical like, sorry, but if you're going to have a label it could be a lot worse than that one, I'm just sayin..
author: Justin N.

description:
Adventuring in the city led us in a mostly sober stupor to Edinburgh.  Met up with a friend and headed inside.  We got lucky as it wasn't busy at all!  We were able to order drinks and find a booth.  Pretty reasonably priced too (compared to bars/pubs in SJ)  - 3 beers and a rum and coke for $16.  

Walking inside it's nothing like what you think you're walking into - it's a pub most assuredly but to have a name like Edinburgh - you would have thought that there would be something Scottish about this place but no.  It's a pub and serves alcohol - as long as there is seating and music what does the decor ultimately matter?  The hand drawn sign above the bar that night read "Korova Milk Bar" which kept making me giggle and many references were made that night to a certain movie.  There are some booths to the right when you come in the front door, more tables and chairs scattered here and there and plenty of stools at the bar.  There is a small stage for karaoke and bigger stage up top (so I'm told) for when they have live music.  I can't imagine how packed this place must get when it's busy.

Since I'm a good bar patron and knowing it was a slow night - when we were done I took our empty glasses to the bar and got a wink and smile out of the bearded bartender who looked like he wasn't having a good night.

The drinks are strong and cheap - bring a couple friends and make it a party :)

I look forward to going back!
author: Jenn S.

description:
I had some time to kill last Saturday night so I took to  the nearest pub with my pal.

I've got to say that our drinks weren't spectacular or memorable in the least bit . I ordered my usual Jameson and Ginger Ale and it was extremely flat and watery ( both times). The same can be said about the 7 & 7 we ordered. Bad night? Who knows.

However, The decorations and trinkets behind the bar  made for engaging conversation. I felt as if I was sitting in Scottish cigar room with family accolades on display.

Speaking of smoke, there is a smokers section.  Naturally this ensures my patronage.  Restrooms are decent,  there is a jukebox , and alert all the hipsters that they serve PABST on tap. 

-Spacious
- Standard prices for cocktails
-Dimly lit
-Friendly faces


Irrelevant fact that will probably only be awesome to me...

This will forever be the bar where my friend got into a fight with someone for making some serious eyes at me. He chased three guys down the street and swung . That's never happened before and I kind of want to remember it.  The drinks may have been flat, but uhhh....they worked.
author: Hannah A.

description:
Great atmosphere and potent drinks. I really liked this bar because of the staff and overall feel. 

Jameson on the rocks...filled to the brim. Few places do this and I appreciate it when they do. 

Good location for a full night out. Several other great bars are in the area along with great late night munchies.
author: Lucas L.

description: Just another bar the pac whites have destroyed
author: blair k.

description:
Edinburgh castle is unassuming on the outside; a tattered awning and a narrow doorway don't do much to announce its presence.  But once you're inside, it's huge (is what she said).  A long bar, tall enough ceilings for balconies along each wall, a raised section with a pool table.  

Trivia Night here gets my vote as one of the best in the Bay just because there was an entire round of Indiana Jones questions, along with music and current events rounds.  

Bartenders were kinda dick-ish.  Acted annoyed when I ordered drinks.  I always hate that.  That knocks it down a star.
author: Matt O.

description: Not a pick - up place nor typical of some other bars.  Great place to meet people and have a meal (good food), even an important meeting.  Great!
author: Thomas H S.

description:
This is an awesome place for Tuesday night trivia night.  The questions are much harder than the ones that are asked at Mad Dog in the Fog.  The trivia master (is that what you call the trivia night host?) is also much funnier.  You'll get a few people that take the competition a little too seriously, but overall it's really fun.  

There's not much selection on food, but that's ok because the fish and chips are awesome, they're even wrapped in newspaper like it's supposed to.  You can actually get combo deals which will save you a couple of bucks o a beer.  They're also usually ok with you bringing in outside food (or maybe they aren't but they've never said anything when I brought other food in).
author: Joe N.

description:
It's alright. Dimly lit with an acceptable selection of beers on tap. I have yet to take advantage of the fish and chip delivery but I hear that it's quite tasty.

I've had some fun times smooching upstairs, downstairs, and had a nice little dance or two. 

There's an indoor smoking room (for those so inclined) and tiny but very functional bathrooms.
author: Loli L.

description:
Dark, muggy, and a dedicated smoking room.  By far one of my top 10 middle-ages-themed dive bars.  

If you're looking for a Trivia Night that you have better odds at winning, head there on Tuesday nights around 8!
author: Peter V.

description:
I would definitely go back to this bar. I ended up there for casual drinks but it happened to be 60s dance night. The dancing was pretty pathetic but I can get down with the music which was northern soul kinda stuff.

The decor is dim and castle-like with flags and lots of wood. There's a balcony if you want to escape the crowd on the main floor. I didn't have any special drinks, but it was a good time.
author: S D.

description:
I guess I should have read about the place before going. Not really my style.
I felt a bit out of place and I know it might sound a bit racist but the main reason is I felt this is a place "by white folks for white folks". Having lived in SF for a long time, I am used to much more "diverse" crowds.
And most of the people there were the hipster type, which didn't help me feel more comfortable.

That being said, I've been to similar places before where I might have felt out of place, but they did have good music. It was not the case here. Plus it was really, really loud and I had to shout the whole time for my friends to hear me.
I also see reviews here raving about the beer selection but I think it's just ok. Again I've been to similar places with a much larger/better selection.

Plus for the pool table and the arrangement, with the 2 mezzanine things on each side.
author: Vithiet L.

description: 20s and early 30s crowd coming here for a cheap drink and a good vibe! I would say it's the best dive bar in SF hands down. Topping all of the dive bars in the mission. Yup.
author: Fredo L.

description:
Came here for the beloved 1964 dance party- which I've been hearing about since I was a wee little one. Now that I'm old and crusty I've finally made it here. The tracks the DJ spun were good dance jams, but the sound was kind static-y. Awesome beer on tap- nice variety and the price wasn't insane- which I greatly appreciate with my tight purse strings. It was dark, but not too dark. I could still easily observe all the SF Hipsters in their natural watering hole- plumage in full colors and styles. 

I also liked all the kooky knick knacks up on the wall behind the bar- not an overload like Van Kleefs, but enough to start a conversation with a sexy dark stranger. 

I dig it here.
author: Nnekay F.

description:
Ended up here Wednesday night on a whim when I ran into two strangers riding bicycles there. Good peoples, A Spaniard Fellow and a Man who looked like a Lion who apparently is the King of Wood Sticks?

The night was kind of a blur but, I remember it seeming like I stepped into the fuckin' 60's when I walked into this place.

Good beer list, and a lot of free spirits.  

Definitely worth checking out.
author: Mark M.

description: Last time I had my fish and chips served up wrapped in newsprint was from a street vendor in Aberdeen on the wharf.  That brings back memories.  And it was good, fish was hot and juicy and the chips were big and crunchy.  All tasted good and with the Kilt Lifter Scotch ale, went down nicely.
author: Brad B.

description:
Edinburgh, I give you a five and I'll tell you why. 

Yes, on Fridays your lines can seem unbearable, and the crowd of hipsters obnoxious. And the music loud, and waiting out in the Loin makes me nervous. Sure, one should not lock their bike outside your doors for fear of theft, despite two cameras at your doorstep. The pesterings of Otis and his constant search for a free tip (usually not his).

But I love you for this, you are my friend, you treat me well, you always have good beer on tap, some fine oldies spinning on Fri., a fun pool table at the top of the stairs, plenty of space, plenty to do, a smoking room so that people can converse and puff, but don't have to blow it in my face, Black Prince Porter (that's for Will, his fav, but one of only two places in the city where we know to find it.)

I love you for that night Ali and I spent all Monday 5PM till 1AM as the only patrons in the bar for hours, that is until Will showed, allowing him to park his ride indoors, and before that when we recruited a couple to come in and have a drink and "no, it wasn't closed, just a slow Monday." Where the lady barkeep thanked us with shots of Fernet and we Anchored the hell out of that evening just talking about life and friends and frustrations and more. And you just sat there and let the magic happen. For that you will have a place in my heart. 

For the first night I met Rachel, and she is the coolest film lady I know. 

For Ali's b-day where a group of us just enjoyed each other's company at a large round table and again, you just sat back and let it happen. 

For ever time I come in and grab a booth with ease and on busy nights a guy comes up and takes my drink order and returns pretty prompt with my suds. 

For surviving the TL, and all it's issues. For surviving the onslaught of vehicles along Geary for that matter. 

For offering Amsterdam across the street should you be too loaded to grant me entrance (which has happened so few times).

For So I Married An Axe Murder. 

You jewel.
author: Kelly S.

description: Nice place right on the edge of polk. Friendly bartenders. $5 whiskey shots before 11 PM. I usually stop by to play some pool or darts. Oh and they have a smoke room as well :P
author: Ravi T.

description:
The music from the digital Juke seemed to make the crowd yell louder.
The bartender seemed more interested in the girls at the end of the bar than serving others.
The waitress seemed to be out of the room more than in it.
The patrons seemed oblivious to the others around them.
- one stepped, no stomped, on my female friends foot with no apology, just stared at her like she did something wrong
- another knocked over a pint of beer on our table and said "You should set that in the middle of the table."

From the other reviews here I obviously need to go back.  My experience certainly wasn't up to that of the others here.

The evening was an hour or two of slow service, poor food, and rude and obnoxious patrons.  This didn't feel to me like any Scottish pub I have been to, more like an American bar filled with Scottish items and young Americans who thought they were acting Scottish. 

And come on, no Tennents?  No Bellhaven?  How about something from the Inveralmond Brewery or the Caledonian Brewery?

They do have Guinness and Racer.  Very good, but not Scottish.  Guinness is an Irish beer, and before any of you utter "same difference" you better think before you speak. I thought they had Kiltlifter, but they weren't pouring it that night (and it's brewed in Arizona anyway).

There are some positives:
- Good selection of Whiskey
- Trivia night looks fun
- they do get some decent bands here
So I will go back.  But I'll probably be back in the real Edinburgh first (already have my plane ticket).

BTW, have you ever tossed a caber?  Not easy.
author: Jeff H.

description:
I usually have a good time here, that being said had I to knock a couple stars off for the dj on Saturday being a complete jerk. He clashed with the good vibes and fun atmosphere of this place.
This wasn't my first experience with a less than friendly dj but this is the first time it's been so bad I second guess coming back.
Seeing as this was my first time even seeing him there I'm not opposed to giving Edinburgh another shot...but if that type of energy is what this place is about now I'll go elsewhere.
author: Ana A.

description:
Decent place, there's lots of seating, a good pool table with lots of room around it, a fully stocked bar.

The fish and chips deal is terrible, don't get the fish. It's ordered outside and it's the most tasteless fried fish I've ever had.
author: Rohan D.

description: This place goes hard. I never have a bad time at this pub. The pool table and jukebox is a huge plus, and the bartender Segundo is the man. WORD.
author: Louie L.

description:
Who thought up the phrase "happy hour" if alcohol is technically a depressant?  Multiple conversations about me, a little ass grabbing, and I'm happy.  Screw the depressant, bring on the joy!

"Happy" hours (plural) indeed...enough needed to DYL.  Not DML, as I was driving that night, but soon, very soon, it will happen.
author: Pam S.

description:
THIS PLACE IS AWESOME!!!!

Yes, outside is a bit sketchy but so park close & travel with a group. 
The drinks are good, not expensive at all & Alan the bartender is a sweetheart. It does get a bit chilly in the bar so dress accordingly
author: Audrey T.

description: Low key, dark, cheap. Don't bother dressing up. This is the low key place you go for one drink. It's a bit dark and dingy in there.
author: Viktoriya Z.

description:
I love random dive bars that aren't packed, have a decent beer selection, aren't too loud, provide ample people watching opportunities, and fun flashback bar music. This place fulfilled all my requirements. 

Walked in on a Monday evening and it was pretty empty, but exactly what I needed. Lots of fun 80s/90s music playing in the background, but nothing too crazy loud. Perfect place for a low key catch up with a friend. I'll definitely be back.
author: Karena Q.

description:
Speaking of hipsters.......

In all sincerity, this place is great. Extensive beer selection, full bar, endless choices. The layout reminds me of Bitter End (Inner Richmond), with the added component of a giant room for smokers in the front. Even though I don't smoke, I'm sure any smoker can give high praises for not being forced to the streets to take in a Marlboro or two. 

The bathrooms are what you would expect from a dive bar. At least here the guys don't have to urinate on a trough filled with ice (I'm directing this at you Mad Dog in the Fog!). 

I hear their trivia night is pretty slammin' too. It's on my ever growing to-do list.

Weekends are busy but not insane. No cover is always a plus, too. 

This hipster-haven is a solid choice in the loin. And when you stumble out of the bar, head next door for a slice at Irving Pizza so you can avoid one less aspirin in the morning. Trust me, with all the beer selections and Edinburgh, you'll need it!
author: Alex O.

description:
I went back again for the pub quiz--still Awesome with a capital A. Hell, AWESOME--all caps. Sure, the quiz is hard, but that's half the fun. Anyways, Carl rocks my socks. When I told him that I was the one who wrote how awesome it was last week, he gave me a free drink ticket. That just made me like him even more than already did.

I really like the collegiality of the place. Everyone's competing against everyone else, but it's friendly competition. Plus, if someone's an ass and everyone knows it, said ass is made to feel unwelcome. Fortunately for all of us, tonight's ass left on his own accord.

So five stars for Tuesday night at the castle.
author: Katie I.

description:
Just came here for the first time the other night!

Yes, it is full of hipsters. Because of the bouncer with the flat top reading poetry, and all the Parliament Lights being smoked in the smoking room, this is immediately apparent. Is this necessarily a bad thing? Not at all! We be rollin, they be hatin.

The drinks are poured with a heavy hand; my vodka cranberries were light light pink. The hipster server with the big glasses and skinny jeans: you rock! He always seemed to know when we needed new drinks, there was nary an empty glass to be had.

There are a couple downsides. The music is so loud you really have to shout to talk to people. I was hoarse by the end of the night. Also, I had to pass a homeless dude trying to talk an old hooker into a freebie on the way here. Baaad neighborhood.
author: Rachel H.

description:
This place is alright I guess.. 

The service is pretty slow and it seems like the bartenders are taking their sweet ass time even if the bar is empty or packed. 

Trivia Night is pretty cool, the round where they play 2mins of a song and you have to guess the song is pretty legit. 

BUT the MC who runs the trivia night seems like a smart ass and rubbed me the wrong way. It started at first when he was explaining the rules and he made some stupid joke about Chico State implying that people who went to Chico State are dumb. I went to Chico State and Im not fucking dumb and I dont want to hear some fat dude with grey curly hair try to make a joke about Chico State. Its like "hey old man have you ever even been to Chico..the bars and the trivia nights their would kick your trivia nights ass!" 

The prices are a little too high for what you really get...if you are in the area might as well just skip this place and head down the street to Whiskey Thieves or even R Bar. 

Sorry not sorry but the Castle is pretty weak.
author: Chris A.

description:
I've come here on a couple of occasions now, and have enjoyed my time here. It's not the busiest of bars (at least the times I went), but if you're with the right group of friends, this place turns out to be one hell of a good time. Pluses include indoor smoking patio with a piano you can play freely, a pool table, darts, lots of booth and bar seating, an upstairs lounge area, clean bathrooms, and delicious fish 'n' chips. Not joking, these might be the best fish 'n' chips I've ever had. Even my British friends agreed they were pretty amazing. I just wish they came with tartar sauce.

One complaint (that really has nothing to do with the bar, and everything to do with sketchy people) a friend got her purse stolen while at the bar (and there were hardly any people there at the time). Just be careful with your things as this may not be the best of areas to leave your valuables unattended. The bartender felt bad and tried to help in the search, but there was really nothing she could do. Lesson learned.

On a happier note, this is a great place to hangout, grab a drink, grab some dinner, and chill out. I'll be making regular visits!
author: Ashley D.

description:
Best night: DJs mixing Motown & 50s all night every 4th Saturday of the month!!

Trivia every Tuesday starting at 8pm is also awesome.
author: Amanda M.

description:
Is Edinburgh pronounced like EdinBURG or EdinBRAGH? Either way, it's a good, solid, place to grab a beer, listen to good music, and hang out with friends.

Yes, it's in a sketch part of town, but the Loin is up-and-coming, right? It may look like a super divey place from the outside, and I suppose in all reality and honesty it doesn't resemble a castle at all, but the great bartenders, the DJ playing everything from Aretha Franklin to MGMT, and some great beers on tap, make up for all of that.

For those of you who smoke, there is a smoking room right in front. There are also pool tables in the back and an upstairs to sit at, but the upstairs is a little too cozy and small for me. Most people tend to stay downstairs where there are booths and tables to sit at and also dancing, thanks to the DJ.

My only complaints are that it is ALWAYS so cold in there and they don't accept cards. Otherwise, this is a great stop in the tenderloin to enjoy a few beers.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
The food here is typcial "pub-grubb."  That's morse code for, "not very good."

That being said, there's that cool rustic, wooden, Victorian interior and social vibe about  this place that makes me return here despite the grease that will make my stomach and digestive system work overtime.

Besides, it's a Scottish place.  If it tasted good, it wouldn't be authentic.

Tip to groupie chicks:  If you are hoping to muse or marry the next John Lennon or Paul McCartney, a lot of English bands who perform at the Great American Music Hall often hang out here.  Get here at 7pm and you're bound to meet an English, Irish, or Scottish Rock Musician.  Don't worry, they are hairy, ugly and desperately in need of inspiration.  They'll fall in love with you in a hurry.

I only call them hairy and ugly because I'm jealous that I'm not as good of a musician as they are.
author: Tony U.

description:
It breaks my heart to have to say this but this once great pub has been ruined. 

They used to draw a crowd of people of all ages, interests, nationalities, and socioeconomic backgrounds now the place is generally full of hipsters.

They used to have bands play in the room upstairs leaving the people downstairs free to talk but the last few times I've been there they had a band or DJ play downstairs making it impossibly loud to hear the person sitting next to you.

The worst and final straw is that the price for a pint of Anchor Steam has gone up to $6. 

I'm not exactly sure why this has happened to my once favorite bar but I'll probably wait a few years before I check in again.
author: Manny F.

description:
Like Vithiet L. said, "for white people, by white people." I don't really understand why people like this place. They have goofy ass nights with goofy ass people dancing all over the place. Imagine early 2000's pop music and middle aged business men with cul-de-sac haircuts singing every word, especially if Eminem is playing. 
Hipsters love this bar and it can get insanely stuffed... I still don't get it... I have to be hammered to enjoy this place.
I came here twice, one time to film a scene for a short movie and the second time because my friend was having a going away party. The first time was bad enough, but when I actually stayed to experience the bar during the second visit.. agh.
An incident happened when I quickly made my way behind the DJ booth in order to get to the bathroom because it was so crowded and nearly impossible to maneuver my way around. It was an open space, so it's not like I snuck behind the DJ or was scandalous about it. However, immediately after that, some guy working for the DJ GRABBED my arm and yanked me back and yelled in my ear, "HEY, DON'T DO THAT!" 
This quickly ruined this already cheesy night for me and put me in a terrible mood for the next 20 minutes we were there. It made me angry enough to confront the guy to tell him that was uncalled for and way too aggressive, especially when I wasn't fleeing away from him or anything. He quickly apologized and although I still didn't think it was necessary for him to grab me, I felt better and left the bar in a decent mood.
Anyway, come here if you're down for crowded places and cheesy white people. If not, steer away from the Downtown scene and head to the Mission.
author: Lori C.

description: Drinks are strong, the area with the pool table is nice. Extremely loud, so be prepared to lose your voice if you're talking with your friends all night. Second floor is narrow and difficult to maneuver around. Neighborhood outside is pretty sketch. Hipsters. Hipsters everywhere.
author: Jennifer K.

description:
Jerks.

1) A friend thought her purse had been stolen (because the bartender placed it behind the bar - which is OK), so I went to the guy at the door and asked him if he had seen anything suspicious. He pointed to a sign that said "not responsible for your valuables" and thought it was funny. Hilarious.

2) While my cousin and I are finishing our last beer at 1:50 AM, we get accosted by 3 staff all telling us that we have to leave RIGHT NOW. We literally had 2 sips left and I tell them we will be done in a second, you guys don't close for 10 minutes.. they get on their high horse and get all pissed at us. They assume I am trying to be a tough guy and impress this girl before I tell them "no, we are cousins, just trying to enjoy our beer.. leave us alone".

3) Don't need a third point.. I don't enjoy visiting bars and restaurants who treat their paying customers with such a lack of respect.
author: Gregg K.

description: Strong drinks + sticky floors + gross bathrooms + pool in the back + drunk tourists = good times. The morning after though, not so great.
author: Peter Y.

description:
Awesome location, I love this place, so many good memories.  I used to go on trivia night.  They have a darts board I believe...or at least they used to.  You can get fish and chips here, and I often do.  GREAT beer selection.  reasonable cover prices if there even is a cover charge.  i spent New Year's Eve here once and it was fun.

I am going to have to not be stingy with these guys and give them what they deserve.  A full 5 stars.
author: Cynthia B.

description:
Great place to just chill, well stocked bar, pool table, and great atmosphere.  Apparently great fish and chips but have not yet tried it.  Bartender's are super nice, I asked for something sweet that didn't taste too much like alcohol (I know, bartenders hate being asked and this is exceptionally girlie but can't throw back those Jamesons like I used to) and bartender was super nice about it and made me something delicious.  I think he made it up on the spot too.

Generally low key crowd, some really interesting people, diverse.  This place isn't that "dive-y" to me but some people seem to think so.
author: Yingjue C.

description:
Feet pounding
Hands shaking
Hearts pumping
Blood flowing

This castle brings one back
To the golden age of music
Where the eyes of young poets met
To gallop through time

Voices erupt into one
To feel the vibration of Dance

The song sings:
"Are you alive?
Well if you are...
Just keep on dancing."

Here is this castle
Where colorful souls paint the floor
For the one less experienced
Jumping in is a complex chore.

Just incase...
Just incase you fall in love
Adventure of the owls
Lies simply out the door.

How many does it take
Until you can remember no more?

A great city this castle
Was founded upon
For where the piece of Europe lies,
The past and future coincides.

Friends are united through dance.
Friends are united through drinks.
Friends are united through smoke.
Friends are united through castles.

No room to move!
God,
I wish there was room to move!
But when I shuffle
To the beat of sound
We all become one
To the beat of our feet's pound.

Stomp.
Stomp.
Stomp.

Life is all intertwined
From frequencies all around.
author: Jon-o G.

description:
I lost my phone here one time and when I called here the next day they asked me if I had the phone with the cat on the screen lol kind of funny but whatever they had it!!
Ok maybe someone was highly intoxicated here but its in a great location actually. The tenderloin has the best bars, at least to me. Go have a few drinks at hemlock then venture out here. 

It is the safest place to lose your phone though. And the best place to meet some randoms.
author: Debbie P.

description:
I was a little in the dumps.  After scoring out for something to do in the Mission, I headed back to my hotel (in the Tenderloin----Eeeeee, I know!  **I had my mace with me**)  ;)  The night was still young (little past midnight on a Sunday), so before hitting the hotel, I decided to do some recon in the 'Loin.  

Edinburgh Castle Pub was something which came up within "walking distance".   Hmmm....Scotland.  I could go for that.  I'm half Scottish.  Maybe I could work on my Sco'ish accent, order a Scottish ale,  and water it down with  a deep-fried Mars bar!

Well, I made my way up to Geary St., avoiding some hookers, and some other ne'er-do-wells in the shadows, and made it to a castle enshrouded in mist:  Edinburgh Castle.....Pub.

Yeah, I didn't expect to see an actual "castle".  Looked fairly tourist-trap-like. I peaked in the windows and saw a few people, but it was fairly dead.  I decided to man up and give it a go.  I headed to the bar.  Other than the barkeep, I was the only other person in this fairly expansive area.  I must admit, I did like the space.  The bar was old and woody.  I saw a grip-load of brews on tap.  Yes, there were some from the Old Country, but there were many local microbrews.  I saddled up to the bar, and went with a "Death & Taxes" ale, and later a Lasgunitas IPA.  I watched the muted Olympic cross-country skiing race, as the bartender watched some sort of British movie awards show.

The bartender was nice, mellow, and treated my loner-self well on an evening when I was in the dumps.  After his award show, he muted his show and popped in some music.  The first song sounded Celtic, but I couldn't place it.  Next, there was a Cowboy Junkies song I had never heard of (but my ears gravitated toward), and then he played a T-Bone Burnett song.  In other words, this bartender was a phenomenal DJ.  All in all, the music, the brews, and the company turned my evening around.  I'd go here again in a heart beat.
author: Corey G.

description:
Bartender: You are bow-tied, and I am expecting some sort of show or charm, but instead you have belittled me with counting tips between pouring my beer and pouring my shot. I need my shot before I chug my beer, otherwise what's the fun? You limped behind the bar, an obvious plea for Yelp mercy, as the premiering student films got glitchy behind me, causing the production team to restart their dated iBook. So over it.

(Also, this place reminds me of Disneyland. See: worn and ripped chairs, castle theme that reminds me of Fantasyland, and the curiously young girls sitting at the bar.)
author: Peter H.

description:
This place would be so much better if they had some solid bag pipers to liven' it up.  

Every time I order a drink here it tastes like the bartenders were low on ice, spaced out while pouring my drink and just splashed some flat soda in it when they came to. 

So, you may get drunk quickly, but you will still feel like something is missing...
author: Slim P.

description: Love trivia nights here!! They have a large turnout and the questions are supposedly the hardest in the city. The food, well, typical greasy bar food. They allow people to bring in food so generally I stop by the Thai House Express and get carry out. The Castle also has a pretty generous selection of beers and some hard liquor. Definitely worth braving the 'Loin on Tuesdays for trivia night.
author: Alice W.

description:
All I could think of when I was here was "This is what the Harry Potter dining hall would look like, if it was a dive bar." And after a couple of drinks I expected a white snowy owl to bring me a letter saying I'd been chosen to play Quidditch this season.

Ok well no, that's not what really happened. We walked here from dinner to celebrate my friend's 30th bday. Yeah this is the theme this year since we're all crossing the divide this year. 

So let's get this place right. This is not a place to order fancy girly drinks at. I saw a couple people annoyed by this, but come on, when there are darts on the wall and no one is dressed up in an SF bar, that equals beer for me usually. 

We had a couple rounds of shots with the bday gal, wasn't too expensive and then mostly tried to chat. It got loud and crowded later on in the night. It's the kinda place where friends could dress however (bday gal was in a 60s wig and super short sequined dress) and no one minded, they even cheered. 

But alas, no Daniel Radcliff anywhere in sight. *sigh*
author: Jessica C.

description: It was once great. It's still just fine. It's destiny will include more greatness. They have an ATM. Barkeeps are randy, treat them with respect, but you can dream.
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description: With its sticky-bartop, scrubbed-wood feel, Edinburgh Castle is the perfect emulation of your favorite Scottish pub. The knickknacks adorning the walls behind the bar - Scottish premier league pennants, old metal flagons, Christmas lights, and tarnished football trophies - give the impression of being in a favorite uncle's living room; the pool table, dart board, and high ceilings further enhance the atmosphere. There is a wide selection of British drafts and local brews on tap, and if it's not too late and you're feeling a bit peckish you can order some good old fish and chips, wrapped in newspaper and delivered while you sip your Boddingtons or play a quick round of cards.
author: Lauren H.

description: It would be a fine bar if it weren't for the old bartender with gray hair who when asked about a beer turned and walked away while mumbling his answer. A good bartender knows his/her beers just like they know the drinks they mix. A good bartender treats every customer with a modicum of respect.
author: Paul L.

description:
My dad's navy buddy who I met told me about how drunk he and my dad got several times in this place. The stuff of legends and old bar that my dad thought was gone only to find it was still there hidden into the look of the rest of the san francisco that changed and cleaned up around it. 

Highland games society meetings I heard used to be held in this location and I am sure they still are..

My dad and I went for a few pints two years ago. When walking through the doors was quickly transported. 3 men in the corner singing old sea chanteys and doing a great job of it too. 

My dad and I each had a pint of Guinness & some fish and chips. Proper fish and chips - someone went elsewhere ( i think they dashed outside!). Didnt matter the fish and chips were the right - traditional way wrapped in newspaper!

very good beer and great food. I need to come back but I think my first experince with this place was so good that my next wont live up to the first. Up on a pedestal as so good and transported in time by this location and its sea chanteys.
author: John M.

description: Cheap, divey, big, got in a fight with my girlfriend here. Totally fun. Cash only. Gets busy late on the weekends.
author: Chris S.

description: Great bar for billiards and large groups.  Fantastic staff!
author: Rachel W.

description:
Where else can you get a pint and fish n' chips for $10? Ten Dollars! When I was in London I couldn't find fish n' chips for less than ten pounds ! (Okay, I didn't really look very hard and I'm totally exaggerating, but still). Not only is this a wicked deal, but to top that off your pint will be poured by a dude with a seriously cool accent and your fish n' chips will be cooked, walked down some dingy alley, and delivered all wrapped up newspaper like some fishy, oily Christmas gift by a little old Asian lady.

The bar itself is chill...dark totally divey. Don't expect to run into your typical Marina folk here, but rather 1, 2, or 15 dudes in way-too-tight jeans.
author: David H.

description: My experience here was a bit weird only because we were there at 7pm on a Wednesday and we were the only people in the place, so I almost feel like I can't write an accurate review of it, but I'm going to anyway because our bartender was so awesome. It was our first night in San Francisco so he was pretty much just chatting with us about the city and played good music while serving us really good drinks. I wouldn't go here for food though. I did have fish and chips and it was delicious, but that's pretty much the only thing on the menu. It definitely seemed like a bit of a dive, but we had fun there!
author: Tami A.

description:
This used to be my bar back in the days of living in the TL and oh how i miss it so!!! Still find myself here when im crawling around on Polk street and have found that it has gotten more and more popular. 

They now have DJs on Fridays and the music selection was amazing!!! Heard anything from Talking heads to Joan Jett, etc. I like the decor and the staff is super friendly. Also the smoking room out front with the piano, i think i always run into some stranger and strike up a random conversation.

Definitely miss being only 1 block from this establishment.....
author: Susanna B.

description: Decent place and good atmosphere, but where we were sitting kinda had the faint aroma of urine.  I think it was wafting from the bathroom.  :-\
author: Jennifer B.

description:
This place has some of the most obscure yet desirable beers on tap I have seen in a bar.  Yes there are a few others in the city, but this tenderloin gem is such a find!  Beers like Kilt Lifer, Dragonslayer, and Kronenbourg 1664 to name a few.  I usually just get the Kilt Lifter, one of my favorite beers, especially on tap, and at 8.5% alcohol I recommend getting their half pints which are exactly half the price of their full pints.  Genius!

This place also has a full bar, decent jukebox, a pinball machine, open upstairs section (rumor has it live bands play up there) great Tuesday night trivia and good happy hour specials.
