If you are a smoker there is a ventilated smoking room complete with beat up piano.  I've been known to wail on the poor beast and sing like a wounded seal with emphysema driving the rest of the smokers outside (usually after too much Kilt Lifter and Fernet).

On the weekends during the day they have free pool and pretty good bloody marys.  One of the bartenders makes a mean "porn star" dirty martitni which he makes by muddling olives and ice together.  It's the money shot of martinis. 

Bring a small flashlight and check out the bar sometime.  It is resin poured over old British pence.  The newest I found was from 1968 and the oldest I found was from 1899. I've been known to pick up some Mexican food from Mid City Foods down the street, bring it in and enjoy some Kilt Lifter and Fernet with my dinner and gaze at the coins with my key chain flashlight, occasionally striking up conversations with random people.

Yeah I'm a sick puppy.
author: Theron L.

description:
Dank bar: I think I love you.

Why do I love thee? 

1) Generous bartender that over-poured every shot.
2) Challenging trivia that makes me want to be a better person.
3) The dank.

See you next week.
author: Tash T.

description:
This one pains me greatly. I have been frequenting the Castle on and off since the mid 90's. Originally it was for the quiz with MC Enzo( who went on to Jeopardy fame). Over the years it has slowly and steadily gone down hill. 

   When they started doing club nights, I though that would be a good addition, I was wrong. The Castle has transformed from a TL locals/ average joe's type of pub and turned into an unwelcoming hipster bar. The current trivia MC is horrible, no sense of humor, unpleasant, a speech impediment( not good to have when running a quiz) and basically a jerk. Service had always been poor and somehow it has gotten worse. The space is cavernous but poorly utalized, always cold and they have no regard to maintain it, rather just let it continue to deteriorate. Prices have climbed, it is mind boggling how a TL bar can charge $6 for a standard pint. They are by FAR the most expensive TL bar you will go to, Hell they might be the most expensive bar in 1 mile radius. Alan seems tired as if he no longer wants to be there. 

   They still bring in the fish and chips from the Old Chelsea, and I stand by saying they are the best in town. So with fond memories and the fish and chips, I can muster 2 stars. It pains me even more to say I will never intentionally go there again. I would love to see that space better used, I shall dream of the day I can buy it and rekindle its former glory.
author: Christopher N.

description:
I've gone here five or so times.
Always a good time.
Strong drinks at an average price.
Usually good music, one night it was awful though, some 30 minute plus disco song, drove me insane. 
Gets really loud and crowded, at least on Fridays and Saturdays which are the only days I have gone.
Lots of young hip people, has a dance floor, a pool table, and an upstairs balcony type thing where it's less hectic.
author: Maciej M.

description:
First night at the Castle yesterday. I think I'm in love. I never deviate from the Nite Cap, but Edinburgh was my friends idea. I'm glad I went.
  Last night was 1964 which means doing the twist to some good old music until the house lights came up. The crowd was eclectic. I thought for sure I would be eaten alive by hipsters in a flurry of plaid flannels and non-prescription glasses. I am happy to say such was not the case. 
  There were only two bartenders on with a full house so drinks took a while. That's the only reason I didn't 5 star it. The music was awesome. By the end of the night we were all doing the twist in a puddle of everyone's drinks. Trust me this is a lot more fun than it sounds. I will definitely be frequenting Edinburgh.
author: Nikki P.

description:
Awesome beer, and I don't even like beer.  People here love to party.  If you've had a painfully long day, week, or just car ride, stop in, let completely f*ing loose and enjoy yourself.

PS:beware accepting invitations to underwear parties, I don't care how cute she is, you've been warned.

Definitely bring a wingman, less as a backup, more as a second opinion.

And lose the shirt and jacket, t-shirt and jeans are fine so save the effort.
author: Mike V.

description:
So, Carl has been conducting the Edinburgh Castle pub quiz for four years now.  It's the most consistently challenging quiz in the Bay Area and none of the questions come from the canned Brainstormer set.  There's a music round (always a plus) and I find the picture rounds to be more relevant than those at the brainstormer quizzes.

I like how Carl has a pencil sharpener behind his "podium." 

And of course, the castle has a good range of well crafted beers on tap, plus Fat Lip on cask.

I just wish that the place had more tables to sit at on trivia nights.
author: Matthew L.

description: Friendly staff and a great selection of beers can be found at this fine establishment. What goes better with a pint than some fried on fried fish and chips action?  Not much!
author: Brian A.

description:
Music was old school soul and doo wop....it was dope. Huge dive bar with lots of space and lots of seating AND a lady comes by to take drink orders which is super convenient if you don't want to wade through the sea of drunken mess and waiting forever at the bar to get the bartender's attention. That's a big plus. 

This is definitely a good spot to meet ladies since there's a DJ spinning good music and girls love the dance. Is it my favorite bar in the TL? No but it's good enough.
author: David C.

description:
My sister lives in Edinburgh and I go there on a regular basis. So I'm in a position to give a expert verdict on this place and that is that it does exactly what it is supposed to do. This pub is beautifully halfway between a pub in Scotland and a pub in America. You will recognize the crumbling decorations of the old country, whiskey jars, football penants and photos of the teams that matter (all teams except them in the blue shirts), combined with an American choice of beers (some of them I had not seen elsewhere in the city) and a crowd that ranged from neighbourhood regulars to metalheads to students with silly sideways hair.  As this place was only a short walk from my hostel, I visited it late at night on 3 or 4 occasions. Bar staff were always in control, even on the busy Saturday night. 

Class act, if I ever get back to San Francisco (and I will) this is one of the first places I'll come knocking.
author: Lennard L.

description:
While not a regular visitor to this establishment, throughout the years I have come to Edinburgh Castle (5 years and running now) and never been disappointed.  The beer selection is good, the bartenders are there to do exactly what they should be doing...bartend!  And the crowd is usually pretty cool.

Definitely worth checking out the trivia if you consider yourself a trivia guru.  Honestly, the hardest trivia I've ever been to and I've been to a lot of trivia nights.

Definitely get the Kilt Lifter (from Moylan's) when you go there.  Best beer at this bar.

Thank you Edinburgh for being a consistently awesome bar.  I wish there were more like you.
author: Melanie N.

description: Its okay. Has a room thing people can smoke in. Has a juke box. Drinks arent too pricey. Bathroom is really tight. But its just okay.
author: Christina H.

description:
Edinburgh is legit.

This is a pretty cool, laid back, dive pub. It's nice because it's not too crowded and easy to get to. It's also fun to walk through the T.L. and people watch on your way there. They have a full bar, reasonable drinks and a great beer selection. They also have a pool table, nice selection on the jukebox and a eclectic drunken crowd. Upstairs is small, not ideal for groups, but it's a nice, cozy place to sit and watch everyone downstairs. 

I don't love this bar and I don't hate this bar, I just kind of like it.

Check it out, but good luck getting a cab.
author: Denise S.

description: Stiff cocktails, Djs spinning (50's and 60's) shoegaze, psychedelic, and rock & roll, chill crowd and no drama. Separate smoking room if you wish for another layer of interesting interaction, and a broken piano to play in there. One of my favorite places in the neighborhood.
author: Y K.

description: you have to give props to this place for having cheap beer. pint of racer five IPA for $4? pint of PBR + a shot of whiskey for $5. pool table. space. smoking room (plus or minus, up to you).
author: Sonya Z.

description:
"If it ain't Scottish, it's crap!"

A good place for weekday/weeknight drinks with an order of fish & chips. Decent jukebox (as good as Treat Street) and a plentiful selection of beers, ales, and single-malt whiskeys... mmm... Talisker. Trivia Night is fun and laidback.

Edinburgh Castle is also a good place to kill some time and liver cells before (or after) a movie at AMC Van Ness.
author: Be N.

description:
We stumbled in on Tuesday night not knowing it was their trivia night and found the place pretty packed...from the moment we walked in, I had one of those "I don't think we're in Kansas anymore, Toto" feelings and that's saying a lot because I don't feel that way very often...I go from chi-chi wine events with my Sonoma boyfriend to SoMa cooler-than-thou hipster parties with the staff at the Bay Guardian with the greatest of ease. I am the greatest of chameleons...but I digress, I felt a little judged walking into this place. Not gonna lie. It started with the bouncer. Maybe I wasn't old enough. Maybe I wasn't Anglophile enough. Maybe my arm candy wasn't scruffy enough. Maybe I was too fashionably dressed and it was apparent even through the very dim lighting. 

I would give this place a five for the service (our server was a no nonsense great at what she does type) and for the beverages on tap, a four for the trivia night (although my favorite is The Bitter End), and a 3.5 for the Fish and Chips. How's that for a score?  The too clean-cut bf loved the Fish and Chips but I'm loyal to the ones at Perry's downtown and The Irish Bank, they're more my style. The batter on the fish was excellent, though, golden, thin, perfectly crisp, not to oily or thick or lumpy, and I did LOVE the proper presentation in newspaper, just like they do in Brighton.
author: Dee I.

description:
So I walked into this bar at 1:50am on a Wednesday night/Thursday morning, walked up to the bar and my group all ordered a shot. It was apparently last call and they wanted everyone to start headig out, so shots we're all they could serve. 
FULL of hipsters, which is always fine by me.

Awesome atmosphere. Great place to have wasted face.
author: JJ C.

description:
This is a neighborhood essential.
A large pub with a homey feel to it. 
Nice and dark, pew seating with a few larger tables for groups.
A smoking area inside to avoid the wildlife of Geary Street.
All the bartenders are down to earth, decent folks who are really friendly.
There's a pool table and a dart board, although the dartboard is kinda janky.
I miss the old jukebox.. the new one is an internet job.. :-/
Fish and chips can be ordered at the bar or from a waitress, and brought over from The old Chelsea.  How can u fail with fish and chips? you can't.
Beer is average in price, their selection of spirits is very well stocked.

I personally enjoy skulking at a table with a couple of mates, pints and dominoes.

They have a range of different events weekly, ranging from a pub-quiz to northern soul nights, poetry and book readings, Gaelic nights and sometimes upstairs they'll have a punk show.

One word of warning is, as this is in the loin occasionally a crack-head may sneak in, so don't leave your coat or other items unattended.
author: Rev Michael H.

description: As an Irishmen I rellay wanted to love this place; gritty, authentic, and their specialty is Fish N Chips! Unfortunately I have not had the opportunity to try them. Service sucks here, and I had no expectations since its a dive bar but I wanted the fish n chips and I waited an hour an they never came. The bartender had no idea and the girl who took my order was off talkin to someone for 30 mins. And the bartender was no help at alll.
author: Sean C.

description:
I don't understand why everyone is rating this place only 4 stars...Yelp really encourages people to be too critical imo. Let keep in mind that this is a local (somewhat dive) BAR...not a fancy touristy venue. 

* Drinks  = Cheap. They have a large bar and usually 2-3 people working behind it so you won't be standing around for too long (except on the really busy nights) before you have a drink in your hand. 

* Music = They play great music from almost every decade (50's-present) 

* Environment = I like my places intimately lit, especially with x-mas lights. This place does the ambiance right. Plus its pretty large. You can chill at the bar, sit at a table, shoot a game of pool, or have a chat with friends upstairs. 

* Crowd = You pretty much get it all, from the working professional to the modern day hipster. I don't like places that cater towards one type of people so I appreciate the diversity. Plus judgmental people suck. 

* The last star is just for being a damn good bar. This isn't a fancy lounge. It's a low key place for those who want a cheap drink, listen to good music, hang out with friends or possibly meet some interesting people. I think they set this place up perfectly for just that.
author: Richard K.

description: Great lady bartender on Monday nights.  This is a fantastic Tenderloin dump.
author: Abigail J. M. M.

description: Cool ambiance but the service makes you scratch your head.  Go in with a girl or else you'll pay a stupid $3 cover.  And girls, be prepared to be sized up by the skinny bouncer at the door, but no worries, it's free for you.  We managed to find a table and order a few rounds, but unfortunately, our waiter took awhile so we just ordered from the bar.  i heard good reviews about the music, but that night i went, sorry DJ, you're stuff aint cutting it. Nevertheless, the feel of the bar reminded me of my beloved Europe and perhaps that is why I'll go back.
author: Alex G.

description:
Great place for a nice large bar.  They've got a pretty good selection of beers on tap and great selection of Scotch whisky.

The crowd definitely gets rowdy and but it's still a great place for a night out to get drunk.

They've got fish and chips from The Old Chelsea down the street and definitely great when you've downed a few drinks.
author: Jason K.

description:
I searched for a local, low-key bar and found it at Edinburgh Castle.  I got there a bit early on a Friday night (9ish) and the place was pretty empty.  However by 11:30, it was packed.  All ages, but mostly 20-somethings.

Had a DJ playing different types of music. Great people watching.
author: Mandy R.

description:
So I only storm the Castle for the Castle Quiz, where I am soundly thrashed each time.  But I'll keep coming back for the toughest and best quiz in town--if only it did not start so late.  Also, I like that the bar is vast, lively, unpretentious, and shaped like a castle (at least from the outside)--and who doesn't want to drink in a castle?  But it could really use a portcullis, and maybe a moat, a drawbridge, and a dragon.  But I understand if that is asking too much. 

Despite the Fuller's sign out front, they no longer serve Fuller's ESB.  That is a travesty, but they still have a great selection of ales and stronger brews that will grow hair on your chest and soften the pain of defeat on quiz night.  If you are feeling peckish, you can order fish and chips from around the corner and have it delivered to you in the bar.
author: Aaron S.

description:
Achtung! Achtung!

Ja vastly overrated hipster hangout!

Mein Gott, it is mediocre!

I am oft enjoying ein Pilsner und Schnapps. Und ja I am oft wanting to hit on hipster Fraulein. So I have this place sometimes gone.

I have better places seen in the trenches on the Eastern Front! Jawohl!

Some barmaid there was very rude, der red-haired Heifer!

But it is close to other, better Bierhalls and Hofbrauhauses, so that is good point, nein?

Also, der Hipsters are not mein Lederhosen liking. Verdammt Hipsters mit flannel shirts and keffiyehs!

Dankeschoen.
author: Manfred F.

description:
So a friend dragged me here the other night, and Im sure glad he did.

Not really a frequent visitor to places in the TL, I wasn't easily persuaded, especially as the outside is a little scary. However as soon as you get through the stained glass doors on the inside you are greeted to a huge cave. I was really surprised with how big it was on the inside.

The crowd is fun and hip, everyone enjoying themselves. The beer on tap was fantastic and the shots are fairly large. Prices where pretty reasonable as well. I read a review where they don't accept cards, however I was able to open a tab on my card with no problem.

The music was pretty eclectic and I hear their trivia nights are pretty awesome.

Definitely a place I would go back to to hang out with friends, great vibe and great bartenders/ service.
author: Joseph A.

description:
Call me a hipster, see if I care. 

I fell in love with Edinburgh when I moved to the city and it will forever have a place in my heart, which I can say for very few bars. The downstairs area gets packed, but is always littered with hot, jobless guys just looking to get hit on. It's cheap as sh*t. The beer selection is great and the cocktails are strong. They have fun DJs and special events from time to time, and the bartenders are always in good spirits, regardless of how hectic it is on the other side. The smoking room is vile, yet I venture in there depending on how many beers deep I am. People like it here so much they loiter outside after last call longer than I've seen anywhere else. I just always have a good time here.

I swore off fish and chips after an *incident* several years ago, but I think it's awesome that they serve 'em. And during the hours that that happens, Edinburgh is truly at its best.
author: Stephanie P.

description:
I think this has everything almost everything I've ever wanted/needed in a bar.

Food, music (and DANCING), great people, nice bar tenders, good prices for drinks, pool table, spacious and big, and I like the neighborhood more than the mission. It hosts a great oldies night full of savory characters. Not much to say except I always have a good time at the Castle.
author: Michelle N.

description:
my buddy lives across the street from this place so I tend to go here often.
Nice selection of booze.
bartenders are nice and straightforward
just wish it had Reeds Ginger beer...
anywho
good for people watching!
author: Alex M.

description:
When a friend said we were going to a Scottish Pub for St. Patrick's Day, I thought she was Einstein. I KNEW she was Einstein when we got to the Castle. Crowded -but in that perfect way. You know the one, where you can still move around to say hi to your friends, and the line for the bar is so easy that people waiting introduce themselves.
BEST, most polite, funny and right on Bartender . Ashley ,@ the bar, was the beautiful and helpful regular. AND Segundo!!, ahhhh Segundo...who put up with a bar full of tables and got our drinks/food to us so quickly and always with a smile on his face, made the night complete.
THANKS TO staff and patrons for one of the BEST St. Pat's Days ever! CHEERS
author: emma g.

description:
Oh Edinburgh, you never fail me for one good reason, and that is for the delicious Black Prince Porter that flows generously from your tap.

But for the others who prefer something other than its dark and robust goodness, fear not. Check out the board behind the bar for a wide array of craft ales, IPAs and other beers on tap. If you're looking for a Bud or Tecate (for whatever reason you would EVER--and I repeat--EVER have to!?), then shy away elsewhere because you're not going to find anything like that here (amen). If you're looking for the hard stuff, they're dressed with a full liquor selection as well, but I can't tell you how they pour for I've really only stuck with the beer. 

There's usually a DJ spinning some funky soul or '60s jive type stuff, and it really gets the hipsters going, I kid you not. If you're not so inclined to join with the electric slide, there's ample seating on the first and second floor.  I usually just make a bee line for the bar, order my porter and head up to the second floor deck to relax with my beer and spectate--all while throwing in a few moves here and there. I dare you to not try to enjoy yourself here, it's virtually impossible.

All in all, an excellent feel-good bar vibe that won't disappoint.
author: Katie O.

description:
Death and Taxes in a pitcher. DELICIOUS DELICIOUS DARK BEER. 

It was a bit crowded and they kick you out if you BYOB, but I saw some chickeedees doin' it in the bathroom anyways. I heard it isn't as crowded as when I went, though -- it's more personal, smaller than other bars. Has an upstairs area and a jukebox. Nice aesthetics. AND a smoking room.
author: Sharee R.

description:
Good beer selection on draft.
Decently priced.
Friendly bartenders.
Been around forever.
Awesome trivia night.
Sufficient seating.
Fish n' chips.

SOLID.
*Throws fist in air*
author: Sarah J.

description:
I think Edinburgh Castle strikes a great balance - the homey-ness of a true San Francisco dive bar along with a tinge of classiness, and a truly amazing selection of beers.

Stopped through here with friends on a Friday night after work.  They have tons of beers on tap with very reasonable prices - a nice reprieve from the somewhat inflated rates of the Financial District Bars.  Also, there were tons of tables available when we got there around 6.  I assume that things picked up later in the evening, but for a couple folks looking for an after-work drink, it was really nice to walk into a bar that wasn't packed to the gills.  I want to come back and try some of their food.
author: Tim N.

description: If you want to grab a cold one in a dark pub so you can plot out your plan of attack, this is the place to go to. I love going here with my cousin who lives in the neighborhood. They have a wide selection of beer, including my Chimay. I love this ale. Dark and rich, it packs a potent punch.
author: Chi N.

description: I was not overly amazed by this place, but it was alright.  The tables are pretty large which is great for big groups.  I like a place with a good beer selection, and this place did not dissapoint.  It really showcased local flavor beers which I liked because I am an out of towner.  That being said, if you are from out of town, this bar is in the Tenderloin district.  Not the safest district in the city, so be careful when walking around late at night.
author: Amanda C.

description:
The place was really nasty.  Just because it's a dive bar doesn't mean it has to be dirty and grimy.  Also, it seemed like a lot of the people in the place don't typically bathe or shower.

The music is too freaking loud, you can't hear anything (not even the music).
author: Lawrence C.

description: It's chilly and has beer, just like a real castle!
author: Klevin D.

description:
After I got past the fact that this bar smells of malt vinegar, I had a really great time!

I went to the Castle for TenderNights (Loiners with Drinks) to meet some neighbors as I live near the TL. It was definitely a divey bar, not some place I'd choose to use the restroom, but it was clean enough that I didn't feel dirty inside or walking out. 

They had special drinks for the Tenderloin event -- they were very reasonably priced and equivalently strong. The atmosphere was very fun. It drew in a good crowd (I'm not sure if I can credit the TenderNights group for that, but I really enjoyed it). 

Great TL experience!
author: Lauren F.

description: My cousin introduced me to this place one night and it was great. I subsequently organized a large event w/ ~ 15 people to here during a weeknight and it worked out as well. Drinks are cheap, atmosphere is relaxed, and the place can easily accommodate large groups.
author: Dave L.

description: This is more like a history not a review of the Castle as it stands now.   Three stars for it then.   Back in the 1970's it was a Scottish bar owned by a Scot and had regular weekend performances by a bagpiper.   It had an amazing selection of single-malt Scotch whiskeys plus taps of many brews.  The purist barman could be difficult with you if you ordered a blended Scotch such as Johnny Walker.  Your personal beer mug (porcelain or engraved pewter) could be left stored behind the bar and would be brought down for you when you came in and sat down.   The fish and chips were very good, and hot.   Darts was one official passtime and could get very competitive, and your personal darts could also be held there for you.
author: David H.

description:
At a few hundred review, jotting down notes on this neighborhood staple is like having an opinion on the moon. Yeah, sure, it means a lot of different things to a lot of people, and sure, some folks might call it God, but in the end, it's a rock in space that controls our tides, but it also is bound to our gravitational pull, which is, in turn, relative to our sun. 

What's that got to do with anything? The place is cool, straight up. Like anywhere in the city, it's bombed on a weekend night, but the bartenders have never given me so much as panicked service, and they do seem to follow a fair and respectable queue at the bar. The upstairs serves as a lucky-if-you-are sort of area, a nice respite. Shows can be intimate as well, but I never really mind that.

I too had a bit of an "episode" with the fish and chips, what my aunty might call "the boots" (and yes, that's onomatopoeic and biophysical). But that was once in how many times. *shrugs*

Seems like they'll always have a thick stock of neighborhood regulars as well as fresh blood come round. Seems like words don't change that. Seems like time is merely time and the moon is just the moon and Edinburgh is what Edinburgh is.
author: Roy M.

description:
Wow, was this place kickass. Walk in and wait for your eyes to adjust to the dark, then grab one of the cozy booths along the side. Order fish and chips to go with your beer and wait for perfection. They even bring it in news-wrap! Service was friendly and prompt (after a slight wait) and the total bill came to $30 for two -- not bad considering we kinda splurged. 

The Castle rules!
author: Allison L.

description:
This is my go to place now that Whiskey Thieves banned smoking.
The drinks are relatively cheap, there's a large open space, you can play darts or pool, and there's a SMOKING ROOM.
Granted, it's kind of gross to be in there after like 5 minutes (sorry lungs), but it's definitely nice when it's pouring rain outside.
AND YOU CAN GET FISH AND CHIPS FROM OLD CHELSEA!  
It's owned by the same people.
God bless the Koreans.
author: Meh M.

description:
Its nothing like a real Scottish pub.
There was no fleck wallpaper to be seen.
There were no urinal stains near the pool table.
The men's toilet seat wasn't wrapped around "wee Jimmy's" neck.
There was no comatose ship yard worker under the pugie machine.
The barmen were too polite - not once did they ask me, "wa ya want tae drink c*ntybaws?"
The was no Tennents lager, Belhaven Best or McKewans 80... but there was Strongbow Cider...
There were no ginger heeded ugly waitresses. In fact no waitresses of any kind. Booo.
I saw no Burberry caps, Burberry scarfs, Burberry jackets or Burberry socks anywhere.
I heard no glasgow banter.
Finally, I did not get chibbed, bottled or knifed for being a catholic.

How I miss the place!
Note to management: Two barstaff on a Friday night is wholly insufficient and squeezes your pipeline for making much $$$. Wake up.

[Bar #2, 5 pints down]
author: Michael H.

description:
I used to go to Edinburgh Castle when I first moved to Ess Eff back in 1998. Then I sort of grew up (or so I thought) and moved onto other bars and the finer things. I do remember missing their fish 'n chips, though, and a very good jukebox to boot.

Forward to this past Friday where I'm there for happy hour, actually to celebrate a friend's birthday. The place hasn't changed much, and that's a good thing. I like the more social downstairs area (where the bar is), but the upstairs seating allows for more quiet conversation, perhaps even introspection on quieter nights.

But one thing will definitely have me coming back, and that is the $3 beers on tap, from 4-7pm. Let me restate: $3 Guinness, $3 Racer 5, yes $3 beer on tap. It's downright glorious, at least for this old man.
author: Nish N.

description: Great beer selection, fair prices.  Can get pretty crowded on some nights, but usually no problem getting a table or booth on week nights.  I've never tried the fish and chips but my friends assure me it's good.  Good juke, and excellent trivia night on Tuesdays. :)
author: Heidi M.

description:
Up until a week ago, if you'd asked me my thoughts on Edinburgh Castle, I would have said...

"I've been to Edinburgh Castle?"

Second only to perhaps Annie's Social Club (http://www.yelp.com/biz/ySs3iPC8-j6jLW5WxZUftA#hrid:wdvJdEekrJ4hLOfu6-HIeQ), this place has been the sight of some of my ugliest, sloppiest, drunkenest behavior. A lot of it I've tried to block out. Black out. Whatever. MAKE IT GO AWAY FOREVER. But, for your reading pleasure, a few BENIGN snippets...

One of only three times I've ever cheated on my diet was after Edinburgh Castle. I don't even know how I ended up there. I went to some party at 12 Galaxies and then all of a sudden I was at the Castle, nearly tumbling down the stairs... THERE MUST BE A HIDDEN VORTEX BETWEEN 12 GALAXIES AND THE CASTLE, THAT'S ALL. So how to straighten myself out? Go next door and EAT A PIECE OF FREAKIN' PIZZA. Augh. It stopped me from THROWING UP, but if you don't eat dairy, and then you DO, it ain't pretty -- what FALLS OUT of you, that is (and nearly during the cab ride home; ack!)...

I also came here with my ex of 9+ years, when he decided to come torture -- oh excuse me, I mean, VISIT -- me for a weekend a year ago. 

ANDREW: (whine) "I don't get it Lisa, whatever happened to us? Bartender! SHOT OF JAEGER, PLEASE!"

LISA: (sob) "I don't know! We had to do this! You know it's true. Please just let it be. Bartender, ANOTHER SHOT OF JAEGER!"

ANDREW: (sniffle) "You realize, after I leave here this weekend it's gonna be different. When I leave here I'm gone, I'm REALLY gone... BARTENDER! MAKER'S NEAT! STAT!"

LISA: (sob) "You've been gone for a long time now. We both know that. BARTENDER! GOOSE ON THE ROCKS!"

ANDREW: (sob) "No, I mean it's REALLY over. You know wernevergonnabethusaaammme... Naheven... Fruh... Bahtendah..."

LISA: "Shottajaaaeguuuhhh..."

And that's pretty much how that night went, on and on, until we were both so disgustingly drunk that we were sobbing and puking all over each other and pretty much had forgotten why we ever found each other attractive in the first place.

Actually, I guess that night was a success.

ANYWAY! Edinburgh Castle = augh. But then -- hey! I went there last week. I did, once again, get WAY TOO DRUNK. And I was WAY TOO SLOPPY. But it was actually drunk and sloppy and GOOD.

My boyfriend's band was slated to play a show there. Just a few nights before, they discovered they needed to do major surgery on the lineup. The Castle was pretty accommodating of their situation and it turned out to be a good night. It put a positive, less shameful spin on my history with Edinburgh Castle. They wound up with a happy ending and a good crowd of friends and newbies alike. Thanks, E to the C!!!

But all those warm fuzzies aside, I guess they DID still wind up with that very-drunk-girlfriend-of-the-guitarist. To which I can only say...

I'M SORRY! DON'T PLAY AT EDINBURGH CASTLE AND TELL ME TO BE THERE AT 10:00 AND NOT GO ON UNTIL AFTER MIDNIGHT! I will drink WAY TOO MANY $3 pints of PBR in that span of time and be WAY TOO MISLEAD into thinking I'm "taking it easy."

I cannot be trusted. We still have that history, you know... This place and I...
author: Lisa T.

description:
(1) 3-dollar happy hour taps
(2) killer jukebox (although it's the MP3 kind - I kinda don't dig those)
(3) pool table - and all the cues are straight
(4) fresh hot fish and chips delivered right into your own little hands
(5) weird passageway to the bathroom that makes you feel like you are walking through the set of Saw IV
(6) yelpers yelping everywhere
(7) how much did I drink?
(8) I have a little hangover . . . .
author: Joe C.

description:
Three stars for the venue and the beer, but minus two for some crap-ass fish and chips.  I had high hopes after reading the reviews, but my fish was so soggy with oil that I couldn't stomach it.

I was there until about 3 in the morning w/my husband's band--how is it possible that the tenderloin is less scary at that time of day than it is in daylight?  Hipsters filled the streets, perhaps obscuring the drugged-out masses passed out in the gutters.  I don't know, but it felt like freakin' disneyland. 

weird.
author: Nikki S.

description:
Came here on a Saturday night after Marrakech (check for the upcoming review). It wasn't super crowded, but it still took forever to get a bar tender's attention (and there were 3 of them). Finally the older guy said, "Give me just a minute." We got 2 pints (there's a pretty good selection on-tap) and a mai-tai for my friend. I usually love anything with rum, but I strongly dislike mai-tais. This one, however, I wouldn't have minded too terribly. Bonus points for that. The tab for the 3 drinks was $18.

They have a juke box and I think there were 2 pool tables.
author: Kate C.

description:
If King Arthur belonged to a fraternity, it might have looked something like this place: iron chandeliers, coats of arms and tankards hanging on the walls to impress the coeds. The young collegiate-looking patrons form their own roundtables near the bar or climb up to the parapets on the second floor, peering down on the lucky jousters playing pool.

Edinburgh Castle lives up to its namesake, right down to the collection of Scottish pennies under the bar top. Scottish flags hang from the ceiling and cast patriotic shadows over the pictures of bagpipers on the walls. For those interested in the great manly sports/kilt conundrum, a caber (a log used in Scottish throwing competitions) is mounted near the pool table, waiting to be tossed. Upstairs, tucked back in a secret chamber, there's a room as big as most bars where live bands and comedy acts perform.
author: Stanley K.

description:
Dear Smelly, Chumpy Boys Who Ruined Anotherwise Fine Trivia Night at the Castle,

My friends did not want you to sit with us, but you rudely insisted on plunking down your fat asses next to us. Not only did you reek of skunk, but your breath smelled of toilet water. Not once did you offer to buy us a drink in exchange for rudely interfering with our game. Not once did you offer up any helpful answers; the only thing emitting from your mouth besides odiferousness was annoying, unfunny, irritating dribble. And here Mr. Man, get a clue: We left EARLY, mid-game, which meant, and only meant, to escape you. My friend did NOT have to work early. Given those circumstances, she certainly did NOT want to give 
you her number, which you bullied out of her and called her right away to ensure it was not a wrong number. Jeez, is that your pick-up technique? No wonder you are surely alone. 

Please do not darken the Castle Trivia Night again. Because, summoning the spirits of my ancestors, I will go HIGHLANDER on your pathetic ass. 

DISCLAIMER: The views depicted above are not affiliated with my otherwise good feelings regarding the Edinburgh Castle.
author: Suzanne R.

description:
There's a weird maze-like hallway to walk through as you enter, and it gets darker and darker the more you go in, so by the time you make it to the actual bar area itself you're pretty much blind (save for the wonderful goodness behind the bar illuminated with lights).  Lots of beers on tap, a couple of ciders - I'm not a big beer person, but I was tempted to try the Kilt Lifter just for the name (I don't happen to own a kilt, so even if I wanted to test the theory out I couldn't).   

The well drinks are ssssttttrrrrrrooooonnnnngggggggg......just the way I like them..........

I'll try their non-seafood stuff sometime, though the food prices (other than the highly regarded fish and chips) are kinda high so we'll see...

Overall, I dug it - I feel like I'd be cheating if I went on a Tuesday, or otherwise I'd check out the pub quiz (it may be a good back up to my usual haunt though).  

4.5 stars.
author: Sus... B.

description:
used to go years a go when they had fish and chips, beer was good and went well with
the food, busy on weekends
author: DJ Y.

description:
Wish we had half stars on here because I think it's closer to 3 than a 2. I realize it is Saturday night but I was unimpressed that there was a $3 cover. To me pubs don't have a place charging a cover but ECP isn't the first or last pub to do this.

The space is huge and I really like the set up of it. A healthy amount of beers on tap, and the scotch and whisky collection that is adequate if not good. Felt a lot of the draught beers were flat which happens but is disappointing. I will say all the people behind the bar seems to be having a miserable time. At least fake a smile here guys!

The decor around the bar is really peculiar. There's a mismash of skulls and other weird decorations. For the vibe that was being sent by the music and lighting it's out of place. Kudos to the DJ who was spinning with records.

I'm personally not a fan of the vibe it sent off. I'm not sure if all nights are similar to this (loud music, lots of people, stressed out staff, etc) if it is then I would not go back or recommend it. If you are young, want to be surrounded by a lot of people and got a mild club feel then go. Personally I won't be back as it's not for me.
author: Timothy J.

description:
Great pub in the tendernob. I love the lighting and the layout of this place. You could opt for a quieter two-person table up top, a big booth with a gaggle of friends down below, or just hangout drinkin' and groovin' by the bar. 

Completely unpretentious, spacious, and lots of things to do. There is a jukebox, darts, and DJ playing funky music.

Also, TONS of beers on tap!
author: S F.

description:
I enjoy the Edinburgh, I enjoy it for the reasons I usually like a bar:
1. They have alcohol.
2. There are places to sit and drink my alcohol
3. It is not too crowded when I usually go. 
4. It is not full of douches and their hangers on.
5. The music is usually pretty good.
6. It is within stumbling distance from my house.

They also have fish and chips, I have yet to have them but I hear they are good and I am sure this will come in handy one of these days when I decide to sit at the bar all day and need a grease fix brought directly to me. 

Also I have always liked the bartenders especially the one who told me he hated me on Sunday. Just enough venom to make me know deep down inside he meant it but not enough to hurt my feelings since we had never met before.
author: Melissa H.

description:
If you're a soul fan - like me! Woot!...go to the 1964 event - bimonthly on Wednesdays and listen to the sweet soulful sounds as you mow down on some delicious fish and chips. Lots of ample seating - upstairs and down...
Do not try to play the jukebox when they are putting out their sweet tunes...I've seen this done more than once and always baffles me. 
You'll rarely find the dance floor empty..almost everyone is friendly and willing to chat it up.

As far as the bar itself...
Great beers on tap - decent price range...
Totally awesome bartenders - whom I've had the pleasure of sitting down and chatting with...if you get their early - say 5pm after a hard day at work...
You have the run of the place and they will swap silly stories with you while you take over the jukebox and totally run around in circles.

It's a win. Total. Win.
author: Katy A.

description:
One of the few safe havens for unpretentious, underdressed cool kids (substance over style people who are hip yet not hipsters -- yes, they DO exist) in the city, & pretty much completely devoid of shitbags.

I approve!
author: Pete J.

description:
Went here the other night for a happy hour going away party for a buddy and was immediately struck by the very cool dimly lit atmosphere, faux Scottish village interior, and best of all the large number of familiar and unfamiliar brews on tap. Being the day before Thanksgiving, the crowd was somewhat sparse and mostly a mix of edgy, artsy, and nondescript.

The Guinness here is very tasty, not too cold, and it takes about 5 minutes to pour which is always a good sign. The bartender was cool and the music tolerable (mostly b-sidey Clash-sounding tunes). I heard the pub grub here is also good.

Definitely worth the walk through a few Sketchyloin blocks. I'll be back to check out more of the brews and maybe catch a band.
author: Nivek M.

description: I like my bars how I like my male genitalia: big, dark and full of beer so when it has an orgasm it sprays beer in your face and you drink it and have a fun time with friends. One thing I like about male genitalia that Edinburgh does not have is pubic hair. They shave this place pretty well, but it's still great!
author: Morgan C.

description:
The anniversary scene from 'So I Married An Axe Murderer' was set here - and fittingly so. Swaggering Irish and Scottish drunks hootin' and hollerin' over the jukebox tunes, lads and lassies stealing kisses behind the booths, and there's always some asshole teetering recklessly on the top railing. 

As for the pub itself, it has most of the ingredients you'd want: it's in the 'loin, has a pool table, trivia night, despairingly nasty bathrooms, and taps that are a few months overdue for a cleaning. Mmmm. Nothing like a pint of warm, dirty ale to wash down those fish n chips...

And seeing as how it IS a Castle... you can expect to see a few members of the local Royal family... the Royally Wasted, that is.

(Minus 1 star for no moat.)
author: Katelin H.

description:
Pretty solid bar. It's a great neighborhood bar but certain nights the crowds can be lame. Its usually better to get a table early on busy nights. Can't complian about the drink prices, except once when a Double-Whiskey Ginger cost me $10. I can't say that thing wasn't big as #@%$ and strong as %$@ though, because it was. That definitely made up for it.
Oh yah, the Fish & Chips from Old Chelsea are the bomb!!
author: Mike B.

description:
The first time I came here almost 4 years ago, I was only visiting from Seattle and had not hung out in SF for awhile.... our trip to quiz night included a crazy old man in a plaid suit screaming at us from the doorway and a homeless man writhing underneath a blanket crawling down the street bleeding. And I think there was a drug bust simultaneously going on down the street too. Everyone just ignored this going on around us as if it wasn't even happening which made me more than a little bit concerned about the city of san francisco.... But hey I moved back anyway! Gotta love the Tenderloin.

This place is still good times for beer, fish n' chips & quiz nights.
author: Brig C.

description:
This place used to be my official Friday night bar...get home from work, get ready and then bus it down to Edinburgh. Originally this was for 2 reasons: 1) a beautiful man that carried a metal suitcase (if you know the bar you know the man), and 2) I love Allan, he was the only Scottish person I knew in San Francisco for a long time and I could always talk to him about "the old country".

With all that said, Edinburgh is still one of my favorite bars in the city, Alan still gives me a free drink when I show up. Sometimes they have a good band playing in an amazingly well sound proofed room upstairs. Any chance I get I convince my friends that this is the bar to go to I do...so please, take heed, and say hello to Allan.

ps. I think the guy with the suitcase is gone...but who knows
author: Laura D.

description:
The Edinburgh Castle has a lot going for it; There's a lot of space inside, a pool table, a quieter upper level, and a good selection of beers. If you're scottish or just hip in a detatched sort of way, you'll love this place. 

However, I am american and mundane and as earnest a person as you will meet. I don't feel like I belong there.
author: matthew r.

description:
Exciting things that happened to me at Edinburgh Castle:

1. Lots of dancing to great great 1960s music
2. Two burly jocks told me a dead baby joke, I was mock offended and lectured them on the improper topic of humor, and they apologized profusely and baught me a beer
3. A guy tried to pick up on me by saying,
a) "Hey, we're both wearing turtlenecks!"
b) "Do you like my comb over?"
4. I almost put someone's eye out with a dart
5. First time I ever tried fish and chips was here. I liked it!
author: Tanya F.

description:
I'll break this place down for you all mathmatic. That's right I'm getting all mathmagicianal on you right now.

(dive bar X hipster bar) + Scotland + live music/ trivia + fish and chips=

Edinburgh Castle

The lighting here always kind of bugs me for the first 20 minutes or so that I am there. Also with the exception of trivia night, there doesn't seem to be any sense of community in this place. I see too many hipsters wearing outfits that were first in style the year that they were born. Not a bad place though.
author: Veronica G.

description:
Close to home. 
Lots of beer on tap. 
Quick Bartender service. 
Comfortable seats for my tired feet. 





WAIT. 
I can smoke my cigarette, drink my beer and dance at the same time?
Done Deal. Edinburgh Castle, you've officially won me over.
author: MJ T.

description:
Bartender was a total b!tch.  One star for semi-cool atmosphere and a reputation that any hipster could rave about.

Me and a couple friends went here for a drink on a Monday night.  It was about 1:20am, so I figured we'd have to drink pretty quickly as they'd be calling last call a bit early but there were people inside so we were stoked they were still open. We walk in and sit at the bar for 5 minutes with no bartender in site.  Finally, bartender walks up and asks what we want.  I can tell she's obviously not overjoyed that we walked in kinda late so I gather my buddies' order and we get 4 shots and a beer.  I put it on a card, close it out, and we sit and talk for about twenty minutes.  She proceeds to pass by us and wipe the counter down numerous times and even pushed her rag into my friend's arm before asking him to move it.  Okay... we get it... we should leave soon.  But the music is still going and people are still sitting.  We're talking about girl drama, and my buddy is venting to me about a girl that basically broke his heart.  She walks by and interrupts with "It sounds like you guys are talking about dogs.  Would you mind taking it to a table?"  I told her we'd be glad to take it outside and that I regretted tipping at all.

There's a reason you're working Monday nights, honey.
author: Matt M.

description:
The fish and chips are the best I've ever had. Well, I have to take that back. See, I was way too drunk to even taste them. But they had to be good! 

Gotta tell you, the service was horrible. Sat at the bar for close to 10 minutes before getting a drink and the place was pretty empty. Next round, we were at a table. Hoping that the waitress who kept walking back and forth would stop. Nope, didn't happen. From then on, just walked directly to the bar. For some reason, and I don't think it was because I was drunker, the bartender served faster as the place got busier. Fairly amazed that the group got sloshed with such slow service... 

Best part of the night. Friend I was with is short and got in an argument with a homeless guy outside who must've been 6'2". First, he called her boo. And she liked it! Then he called her slow. As in you must be retarded slow. Hilarious. You had to be there...
author: The Sock S.

description:
What did I drink, I dont know. The other people..I don't remember. Sleezeballs? Yes, Perhaps so.
I do think it resembles bars in the UK (London, really).  So, one of the 4 above is a hot-to-trot, brittish-accent-covered, international star.
My 1st time at Edinburgh was to see Matt L's (on yelp) band, "Parting Glance" play. The show was on the top floor, in a tiny dark room that feels like your attic from back home. Not a great music venue. Still, the jukebox offers a great rock selection and I thoroughly enjoy the make-shift carpeted dancefloor.
author: Nicole L.

description:
I stopped at this place after seeing a show at the Hemlock Tavern just down the street. I was pleasantly surprised when I walked in. Great selection of beer on tap, and it was much less busy on a Friday night than the over-crowed Hemlock. The feel of the place is great. Two floors, with an open walkway upstairs, and a pool table. The music was right on, and it seemed the crowd was pretty decent as well. 
We sat downstairs in the pew like booths with the long wooden tables. 

It was the end of the night, so it seemed many people had hit their limit already. Especially the young lady sitting at the end of the bar making-out with an older gentleman who's arm was elbow deep into the back of her pants. Nothing like public finger bangin'. If that wasn't entertainment enough, she then proceeded to climb onto the bar to dance...or something, but ended up knocking off a few glasses and bottles instead before the bartender told her she had to get down. Dangerous, I know, good thing the older gentleman had is dirty paws planted tightly on both of her breasts to help her down!
author: Crystal R.

description:
This is both the perfect place to bring the people you are really close to and love, as well as the perfect place to bring someone you absolutely hate and despise.   

It's both the perfect place to bring a girl you've been out with for a long time for a nice change of scenery, but perhaps an even better place to break up with her.

One step inside and you realize that this is pretty much the exact setting for a place within the tenderloin district.  It is British themed in a sense, and it looks as if it were built at the time that the English were still ruling the colonies.  It's no coincidence that you can't spell Edinvurgh Castle without d-i-v-e.

However, any real man knows that there's just four things a good bar needs--a good beer selection, pitchers, glasses, and seats/stools for when you've had too many and don't want to have to fall to the ground.  Edinburgh Castle does well on both accounts surprisingly, but the overall cheap, rustic atmosphere is what makes it work. 

Some notable points:

*The only faucets are found within the stall of the bathroom, so if you use the urinal and someone's in the stall, you have no choice but to wipe on your pants.  
*The ATM spits out $10 bills.  

If you're looking for a night to go here though, go here for trivia night.  It starts at 8:30 on Tuesdays, and the entertaining "MC" takes you through seven rounds of questions, from Kevin Bacon topics to current events to music.  Prizes include free beer, as well as cold hard cash.

Just be sure to arrive with either some really smart people, or someone with access to a PDA phone with internet access.  

Unfortunately there's no wifi points in here...though, if you're surprised at that fact, this probably isn't your kind of place.
author: Tien N.

description:
Terrible.
Everything.  Terrible.
I'm Scottish, and have been to Scotland many, many, many times.  I read reviews here on Yelp and was very excited to try this bar.
Maybe my expectations were too high.....
However, I went to this bar looking for an authentic Scottish pub.  There are a lot of Irish bars in every town, but never Scottish bars!

They had zero Scottish beers there.  I know, I know, Scotland is known for its Scotch.  HOWEVER, along with my Scotch I also enjoy Scottish beer.

None.

They had lots of Irish and English beers, and a wealth of microbrews, but not one Scottish beer.  Shame on them!

The service was so terrible it was virtually non-existent.  Truly.

We made a decision to try some of their fish and chips dishes, and they were equally disappointing.  

For my expectations, this was a terrible experience.  And hardly Scottish in any regards....

It was an average dive bar in a ghetto neighborhood.  And that's about it.
author: Sarah H.

description:
I love this bar for embracing what it is: an awesome hole in the wall watering hole!

It helps that I live a few blocks away but this is one of my favorite places to go.

They always have an amazing beer selection and the pool table is the best I've played on in the city.  

I've been there almost every day of the week (not in the same week jerk! I may be an alcoholic but I like to spread the love around). And I've yet to see it really packed. That being said I almost always meet new people at the pool table and have yet to have a bad experience there.

From what I've seen the main area by the bar never really fills up but the pool table area usually get hoppin' by 10:30. 

Not the classiest place in the world but one of my favorite bars in the city!
author: Nick E.

description:
word,

Edinburgh castle is an great bar for sitting around with friends and having a beer. It resembles a brothel or haunted mansion inside (but in a good way) and has nice big booths to sit your fat-ass in and plenty of good local and English beers to keep you plastered. Their fish and chips from Old Chelsa is go nicely with your pint.

What makes or breaks a bar for me is the music. Edinburgh's jukebox is awesome with a nice selection of punk/grunge/80s songs you wont get in most bars. Another thing that makes or breaks a bar is the noise level.  A bar isn't a club, so i should be able to talk my friend normally without shouting. Edinburgh unlike similar punk bar Hemlock, I can talk to friend without going hoarse. 

Plus they have a pool table and darts, which any self-respecting trying-to-be-a-British/Scottish-pub should have.

cheers on this place. Up up and away

yups
author: david h.

description:
Best hangout bar in the city. The only catch with this place is you won't meet any women there. That's the way it should be though, a fine hangout establishment like the Castle would be ruined if it turned into the meat market. Pick a girl up at R Bar, then take her to Edinburgh Castle the next night to see if she's "cool".

P.S. It's been said a million times, but it has a great Jukebox!
author: Dan M.

description: Went here to hang out with the guys on one Thursday night. They shot some pool and had a few pitchers of beers. It lies right on Geary by the TL and so parking is a quite hairy. The bartender is the owner and he was really nice. They only serve fried foods. Cheap eats. Alot of people seem to gather here since it's a pub. I'd come back!
author: Mika D.

description:
This is my new favorite pub, I only wish I were closer so I could come here all the time!

I came here with a few girlfriends after having an annoyingly trendy experience at Jade Bar a few blocks down, and this was a refreshingly perfect counterpoint. Wonderfully divey, mostly empty when we got there but apparently hopping on Wednesday and weekend nights, and great bartenders - very attentive and friendly. My boyfriend had some questions about the huge array of scotch they have, and was thoroughly schooled on the topic by the knowledgeable and helpful bartender.

Apparently they get their fish and chips from a place around the corner, and the fish is light and sweet while the chips are crispy and yummy. Perfect, perfect! We got a couple of pitchers of Smithwick's and enjoyed ourselves immensely. 

We will definitely be back, both for dancing and for the trivia night on Tuesdays.
author: Devora Z.

description:
cool music, laid back atmosphere, full bar, fish and chips if you like, tables and chairs and a dance floor. dimly lit, can get pretty loud, filled with a nice crowd. at times you'd see the odd old guy who totally looks out of place, but its still chill.

there's no smoking and just in case you don't know, there are two signs in the entrance to remind you. there was a wait friday night around midnight... rumor has it they got busted for going over the 129 occupancy load so you can't go in unless someone leaves.
author: Lauren Y.

description: Very plastic Scottish pub - but conveniently located and it is a cosy little place for a chit-chat. Fish and chips (coming from piccadilly just down the road, i believe) were a great disappointment, unless you were already drunk. The audio/sound system (music/tv - we went to watch footie) was mediocre.
author: Mikki G.

description:
Edinburgh Hipster Castle Pub
Now serving all you royal hipsters beer, hard liquor, fish & chips in a dimly lit castle environment. 
WARNING: You must wear big black rimmed non-prescription glasses. 

So if you are a hip hoppin pop lockin hipster immediately take yourself here. Architecturally neat, it seems to have a mix between a castle and a log cabin feel. This castle is dimly lit with a sea full of people on your usual weekend night. Hang out at the tables, or indulge yourself in a game of pool or darts. But be patient, there's only one pool table and dart board (sharing is caring!). Make your way upstairs as well, but oddly the two sides of the 2nd floor don't connect. If you want to enjoy music (dj or music guest) there is another room upstairs in which you will be required to pay an entrance fee (I believe it's no more than $10). 

They have a good selection of beers and hard alcohol with your usual average drink prices. With the normal busy bar scene, the bartenders were pretty nice. One bartender couldn't remember how to make a drink, but gladly asked me the ingredients and proceeded to making it. As we ordered more drinks, they become fairly generous and therefore we had stronger drinks (yay!).

Food? Yes they have food. Fish & Chips, that sort of thing, but it comes from a place down the street. According to the sign it takes a little longer due to that.

Overall the place was clean, and busy as any other dive bar would be. The usual bathroom situation for women: a line. 

What I take away from this experience: "hipster" black rimmed glasses that eat your entire face up are overrated. they don't make you cooler...
author: Catherine O.

description:
Confession time: I pretend that I am Scottish. Ok, yes, if you take a look at my family tree, I very much am. But the F family came over long ago with the Mayflower. There are no kilts hiding in the closets at my parent's house. My family just eats a lot of bangers and mash and sings "Auld Lang Syne" when drunk.

That said, I like my pubs. I like them dark and dingy, with ample amounts of beer flowing from the tap. I especially enjoy those pubs if some dark rugged Scotsman is getting me a drink - hellooooo Gerard Butler!

But strange things are afoot at the Edinburgh C....there aren't any of my brooding Heathcliffs hanging out at the bar, nor are there any loveable football hooligans wandering around drunk.

Instead, there are just lots of hipsters hanging out and looking way too cool for more than staring contests. I enjoy staring contests. In fact, I generally win them. But not in a pub.

I haven't been there on trivia nights, so maybe it's different. Maybe one day I can wander in on a Tuesday and fall smack in love with a lovely gentleman quoting Robbie Burns...but to borrow from that masterful poet about my exit:

"And like a passing thought, she fled
        In light away."

We got the hell out of that place and instead chose to roam with the cracked-out crutches guy on Geary. Super.
author: Devon S.

description:
This place will forever been to known to me as the "sock hop".

I came here on a Wednesday Soul Night, because I am a big fan of 50s and 60s soul music. The night started off a little slow, but by 1130, the dance floor (located upstairs) was PACKED with (sorry to use the phrase) hipsters, who seemed to have claimed this place as their home. 

Surprisingly, this didn't bring down my experience - it actually made it funnier! 

Why this place rocks?
1. great selection of beers on tap
2. great prices for beers on tap
3. Huge spacious area - with seating (please see my Elbo Room review)
4. One night of the week where the dance floor is dedicated to celebrating the magic of soulful music - where the people actually forget about looking cool and just get down with they bad selves circa 1964.
author: Crystal A.

description:
My local spot. 

My whole in the wall.

My cheers. (Where people either know me as Mari, that drunk girl, or that fine broad.)

My neighbors. 

What I really love about it, is that there is always something different going on there:

*If you are into trivia, you have your choice of Tuesday trivia game night. And, hunny, don't worry, they WON'T Take it easy on you. 

*If you love the sounds of the happening 60s...perfect! Wednesday night's are all yours! Amazing dance party, 1964! Look up their Myspace and check out some of the tunes they spin. 

*Occasionally they'll have bands playing...they'll have dj's spinning some reggae beats..old school hip-hop. 

*if you go in on a mellow monday, you have the choice to work your magic on the jukebox. The selection is very large. 

*Did I mention a pool table? How about a dart board? Well, yes, they have that too. 

*They're choices of beer are impressive...all though Midas Touch is no where to be found.. **Hint -Hint***

And don't be frightened because it's in the TL...people are harmless, I think it might be from the contact high folks get from standing close to the cannibus club right next door. 

I ALMOST FORGOT TO MENTION! If you're hungry for something to eat, you have the choice to order food from the local fish and chip joint. They will personally deliver it too! The fish and chips are awesome! They have tempura veggies, fries..yummy!

I heart Edinburgh!
author: Marivel M.

description:
I enjoy this place....its different. The beer is very good and the menu
is good....also the fish n' chips which  they served it  in news paper.
So not only you can enjoy the beer and your fish n' chips but
they also provide you reading materials......Sometime they even 
have some guy play the bag pipes....its a fun pub....
author: Der Maibaum L.

description: I like to come here when I have time to kill in the early evening (usually a meeting or event downtown) and can sit by myself with a book and a beer. Other times, don't care for it so much. Too loud, and last night the guy wouldn't make me a sazerac. A sazerac, a good, honest, New Orleans-invented old school drink which is basically a huge shot of rye. Then when I ask for a rye and soda, we find out he's out of rye anyway. *No* rye? This is a full bar, correct? Not one little bottle? I'll still come here to kill time, but otherwise I'll do my serious drinking at KoKo's, up the street. PS: I think the  writer-owner of this place has done great things for SF's literary scene. So, I hate to disparage the joint, but as a professional drinker (I write about alcohol and one of my editors was with me last night and we were talking rye) it bothered me.
author: Josh K.

description:
Categorically speaking, I hate pubs. Edinburgh is the exception that proves the rule. I dig the look and feel of the place, which is old-timey buy not trying too hard about it and not hokey, either. You probably don't have to play Dungeons & Dragons to like this place, but it helps.

Also categorically, I try not to have dirty thoughts about anyone who's working at a place I'm visiting. But I had to make another exception for our bartender, if you consider it dirty to want to eat ice cream off somebody's shoulders. She had really good shoulders! But the Castle does not serve ice cream, so I had beer and rum and left my sordid disappointment hanging on a pool cue in the corner. It was a weeknight.
author: Wayne W.

description:
Friends: We're at Edinburgh.  You should come!
Me: Uh, I'm watching the debate and doing laundry.
Friends: It's Trivia Night and we just ordered some fish 'n chips.
Me: OKAY, I'll be there for the next round!  *stops dryer, throws 2 wet loads into laundry basket into the car*  

At Edinburgh:
Me: *sitting down, pouring myself a pint*
Friends: Do you know Wendy's, from Peter Pan, last name?
Me: Yeah, "Darling." 
Friends: Cool!
Me: *drowns chips with malt vinegar*

Love Edinburgh.
author: michelle s.

description:
It's Wednesday, close to midnight, and here you are at Edinburgh Castle. About a dozen people are hovering around on the sidewalk indicating that the inside is probably pretty packed. The door guy has a bored look on his face as he checks your I.D., while you stand in a cloud of smoke being expelled by skinny jean clad 20-something-ers.

As you walk in, you think back to the 1st time you were at the E.C. What was it, '98? '97? A long time ago, when it was brightly lit and filled with average Joe's out for a post-work pint. Tonight, it looks like a frickin' hipster bomb went off, because all you see are shag hair cuts (circa 1982), studded belts, horizontal stripes, and Vans. Whatever. You're there, it's been a long night and a drink is in your future.

While the clientele has changed, you notice that the bartenders have not. Rough around the edges, the handle-bar mustached bartender gives you something close to a "What'll it be?" Your friend looks scared. While he does seem a bit intimidating, you flash a smile and keep it simple. No pink drinks here. This is a beer and shots kind of place, so you order a couple of Fernets with ginger backs. All paid up, you grab your drinks and step aside for the loaded couple who are practically falling over each other and you. A couple of frat boys who seem to have lost their way to the Marina make a sloppy attempt to chat you up. Not in the mood, you find your way to a big booth and toast your friends at the sheer luck of finding seats on such a crowded night.

Overall, as your crew starts to get a little boozy, voices growing louder and louder, you notice little things about the E.C. You see it for what it is. A dive bar. There's a red lantern candle on the table giving off a nice rosy glow. The music is really loud, which is why you can't hear anything significant from your friends conversation. You like that he drinks were pretty reasonably priced, and once you got the bar keep to crack a little smile through his handle bar 'stache, you think that the staff is almost friendly. You also realize that their service style is not completely inappropriate considering the crowd of inebriated hip kids around this Tenderloin bar.

You yawn. It's really late. You look over to see your incredibly drunk friend weaving and wagging her finger in the face of a tall hipster guy who has a mildly amused look on his face. Yep. Party's over. It's definitely time to leave. Once you get outside, standing in the cloud of smoke that's still lingering, you think to yourself, "That was actually pretty fun. I'll be back."
author: Tiffinie T.

description:
My roommate and I frequented this place regularly for awhile.  It's gotten progressively busier and more hipster lately.  Tad dangerous on crowded nights too.  (Girls I would recommend you watch your purses at all times. Friend of mine had hers stolen here before.)

They have some really great bands playing here on weekends.  As well as 1964 upstairs on certain nights where they play some amazing tunes. (The talcum powder on the floor makes you glide and look pretty smooth.)  On side note:  They tend you start kicking people out prematurely and usually rudely.  Never really liked that.

Some bad experiences has led to me other places as of late but it will always be our local fav.

UPDATE: (1/13/07)
I've been coming here more often lately and yeah...I still do really love this place.  What can I say?  Once the bartenders get to know you it makes a bar that much friendlier a place to drink.  I'll always go here, it's big inside, dark, tasty food, good jukebox, I run into friends here, and it's literally around the corner from me.  I can't complain.
author: Mary R.

description:
Cool pub, but they were out of Newcastle last night...  That, was not good!
Looking for it, we walked right by it.  Watch out for the small sign.

They have what it looks like an awesome collection of whiskeys.  Must try some next time.

Not crowded on a Tuesday night, which made it easy to have conversations and relax.

Loved eating the fish & chip here!  It's delivered from Piccadily Fish & Chips just up the street!!!
author: Yamil A.

description:
I love this bar.

It's got some solid character--and not like they went down to the thrift store and bought up some kitsch, but like a place that people come into, and depart from, and leave their fucking mark.

Awesome selection of draught beers, good liquor, and the owner and staff are community-involed--that means that they *do* *shit* around town, put their money and time in the area, and are generally good fucking citizens.

They lose points for two reasons:  first, they charge $4.50 for some beers, which is suuuuuuper-retarded.  What bartender wants to deal with coin?  What patron does?  Please--raise your prices $0.50 or lower them $0.50.  Stop annoying everyone.

Also, their mixed drinks need work.  Manhattans do not come in shot glasses.  They don't need to be in a stem glass, but for god's sake, a Manhattan with chipped ice in it, and poured into a shot glass is a fucking embarassment.

You know this is an awesome bar because they can fuck up a Manhattan and I'll grin and order another.  This is just a fun place to hang out.  They could serve PBRs and deli meat and I'd still come here.
author: Martin W.

description:
I had such a fab time the first time I was here so was very excited when a ex- co-worker picked here as her farewell send-off. I was all ready to revel in the pseudo-European pub/American bar mix, knock around a few balls on the pool table, muse over the antique-y Scottish knick knacks, move my hips to Tom Jones and Bug-Thugs-N-Harmony tunes, trying not to put anyone's eye out with darts, and generally just chill with a pint of Hefeweizen.

I did all that but decided I must partake in the famed fish n' chips. I was told they're greasy. Perfect to soak up the beer I had. So I order them. A couple of girls order food around the same time as me. I go back to my group, knocked some more balls and moved to "What's New, Pussycat." What a great song. And boy, do I suck at pool. Can't even hold the stick right, and I'm sober! Hit the white ball into the pocket a couple of times. My friends try to be encouraging, but who are they kidding? I SUCK! "Superfly" comes on the jukebox. Then the Clash. Fantastic, my kind of music. 

...WHERE THE FUCK ARE MY FISH N' CHIPS?

Seriously, after what felt like an eternity, I had to go ascertain the whereabouts of the fish n' chips. I was like, how long does it take to fry a freakin' piece of fish? A sign posted over the bar says "During busy times delivery of fish n' chips may take up to 30 min." I look around, there are only 4 groups tops. It's been like over an hour! I'm literally aging over here. My friends tell me they're actually made up the street at some joint, and a Chinese guy brings them over in batches. Then I recall seeing said Chinese guy coming through with a box a little while ago. I go to the bar, and I see the girls who had ordered around the same time as me eating their fish n' chips! AHHHHHH! Did I miss the boat? I go over to the bartender, who seems kind of moody, and say I'm still waiting for my order. He tells me it should here soon. Fine. Whatever. I wait some more. 

Finally, Chinese guy's here! He brings my order and a friend's order. I open it and it has 3 pieces of fish, and I ordered 2. My friend's order also isn't what he ordered. I was like, I ain't giving it back, I don't care whose it is, I get this extra piece for waiting that long. It better be the best damn fish n' chips EVER. 

And actually, it wasn't bad. Batter pretty crispy and meat pretty soft. I didn't care for vinegar on the fish. The chips were less satisfactory, but by then I was so hungry I could eat shit. Next time? Just go up the street and get it directly from the Chinese guy yourself and bring it to the pub.
author: Linda L.

description: Not bad. I'd give 'em 4 or even 5 stars if they offered a cheap tall can. This place is essentially the Beauty Bar of the TL, with less pretense.
author: Kaleb S.

description:
It's comfortable.
The place is not too cheap and not too fancy.

Of course there is great happy hours and pool table. 
You can get fish & chips if you are hungry. 

I wouldn't go there on weekend when I want to party and dress up but it's the perfect place for drinks after work. 
It's pretty big place so happy hour time is pretty empty which I kind like. I have never actually drink cocktails there. Always drink beer or scotch/whiskey. I wonder if their cocktails are any good...?
author: Green Mango Y.

description:
The walk down Geary from Van Ness and the stinky-feet smell of this place just can't keep me away.
I love the feel of the place- the bartender, the dark wood, the pitchers of Guinness and Kiltlifter.  The guys who sit around a table and play Irish drinking songs every last Sunday of the month.
This is the closest thing to being in Cork or Dublin that I've found in the city.

Every time my cousin leaves for Ireland, we knock down a few pints at the Castle.

Make sure you try the fish 'n' chips and fried zucchini, yum!
author: Jessica P.

description:
One star for the juke box.

Another star for the pool table, darts and pinball machine. 

Plus one star for serving fish and chips.

Final star for the decor. Little twinkly lights bring some charm to this dark, dismal place. It seriously reminds me of the Pirates of the Caribbean ride at Disneyland. You know this spurred a run of Pirate Jokes. 

Q: What's a Pirate's favorite pattern?

A: Arrrggyle!!

Minus one star for the douche who kept free styling in my ear as if I hadn't heard enough. Seriously? Seriously.
author: Jenny S.

description:
Whenever i'm in SF, i make sure to spend some quality time here. Never too crowded, and even if it is you can escape upstairs to the peanut gallery. Atmosphere is wonderful, can't be matched anywhere in the city. Once, while lounging in a booth, my license and room key fell slid out of my dickie pants. Unaware, my friend and i left to roam chinatown and north beach. Tried to get in somewhere else, discovered my loss, rushed back to Edinburgh, checked the floor, and praise the Castle, it was all right there.  It'll always have a place in my heart.

Pool table, great jukebox with lots of punk rock and roll. Great selection of beers on tap. A classy dive in the heart of the tenderloin. The fire glows. Some arcade games back near the dirty bathrooms. Good tacos across the street and pizza right next door. Where black bums come in and offer you a bottle of shampoo for a dollar. Just a few reasons why i love the place.
author: Tim O.

description:
I hold this place very dear to my heart. There were at least 3 or 4 going-away parties that were held here, one of which was my own. In 2006, I lived directly across the street, and what a wonderful year that was! I recently went back a couple months ago, and it's changed. Word must have eventually got out on how awsome this place shreds, and now it has been completely taken over by the hipster, rats!! Ah well, the time's they are a-changin'...

Everything is of wood inside, booths are abundant downstairs and upstairs...though if you're upstairs, be careful along the rail (especially if you've been drinking one too many). There is one bar, and there are servers, both of which are punctual and ready to serve. The restrooms are pretty dingy, but you will not notice 2 pitchers in. There is a pool table and dart boards, both of which I don't think I've ever used. There is a jukebox, with some fantastic tunes. And there are...........Fish & Chips.....delivered direct from The Old Chelsea around the block. Listen, I'm not kidding, try the Fish & Chips. They might be the best Fish & Chips you've ever had.......yeah, I said it

DO:
Eat the Fish & Chips
Drink Magner's on ice
Drink Radenburger by the pitcher

DON'T:
Forget to eat the Fish & Chips
Physically touch anything in the restroom
Lean on the railing upstairs
Forget that you're in the Tenderloin
author: M S.

description:
A coworker of mine was playing at the venue upstairs. We all decided to head out there, and I of course brought a few of my cousins and had a great time. Never been here before, and I was a tad confused as to where the hell to go to see the band. Apparently it's in a "back" area upstairs. Who knew?

The beers were good and the fish and chips were better! They got fish and chips! I love tartar sauce....TAR TAR SAUCE!!! (relish and mayo) What no one likes tar tar sauce? It goes with both fish and chips....not so much with beer. 

Good luck with parking - fortunately all I had to do was give a homeless guy $5 to get up out of the street so I could park....and not only did he get up...he said he'd watch my car. Love SF!
author: John-Michael C.

description:
Boddington's on tap.  
Tuesday night trivia night.
Fish and chips.
Enough said.
author: Mitzi C.

description:
Honestly, this bar should get 5 stars.  They have a ton of great beer on tap and their scotch selection is impressive, they have a pool table and darts, there is live music every now and again, they sponsor events for writers, the JUKEBOX IS AWESOME , yet the smell of this bar is so repulsive to me that I can't stay for more than a half hour.  

Now I understand that most bars will have a bit of a funk to them from the food, the booze, and whatever else is spilled around, but there is also another issue I have with the odors that emanate from inside of this establishment.  

Last night I had the good fortune of literally being surrounded by the worst smelling humans on earth.  It was like they formed this invisible odor circle around me that made even my black prince porter taste like their 2 month old musty sweat.  Now of course a bar cannot be held responsible for the smell of it's patrons, but damn.  Can they put a shower in the back?  I'll do the plumbing for free and throw in a year's supply of soap.  I mean, I still am getting wafts of BO while i sit here and it is making me physically ill.  

note to the man with the little black dog sitting at the table behind me:  you are fucking gross and it is not very hygienic when your hair looks like you just got out of the shower when it is plainly obvious that you have not set foot in a shower for the past month.  

If you can stomach the scent or you in fact are an incredibly smelly person, this bar is great for you.
author: Charley B.

description:
My review on the Fish N' Chips. YUM! The fish was real good. It arrives all wrapped up in newspaper like a Sub. The thrill of unwrapping the newspaper makes it an exciting moment especially if you're starving. It was cheap and not too greasy either. I give it a thumbs up.
