Once again it was strips of fish, Like chicken strips. 
I realized I will not find New England fish n' chips because this isn't New England :-) But i can get something close. 
P.S. They get 4 stars because were missing the lemon to squeeze all over my fish and the fact it was strips. I want the whole fish baby!
author: Shelley S.

description:
I love this bar.  I am going to share with you all the reasons why:

-I am obsessed with Scotland
-It's divey but spacious enough so that it does not offend my claustrophobic tendencies
-Decent jukebox with all the essentials
-Fish and chips can be delivered to you from nearby if you get a hankering for it
-Decent beer selection
-Perfectly stoic and aloof Scottish bartenders
-Conveniently located in my neighborhood

When I think about the day I decide to leave San Francisco one of the first things that goes through my mind is "but how will I get my Edinburgh Castle fix??"  Well, the answer is simple:  I won't.  

That's a damn shame.
author: Carla C.

description:
in honor of just receiving my 2009 elite status i will review one of my favorite watering holes.

Edinburgh castle might not be much of a castle, but it has been with me through some of the best and the most embarrassing moments in life.
I can always count on a good beer/whiskey ratio in my system. good music, good people, and no attitudes.
author: Helen N.

description:
Large dark space with plenty of shadows to hide in.  Great beer selection although I almost freaked when I saw Belhaven on the board but they don't have it on tap anymore.  

Dartboard, pool table, good jukebox.

Upstairs back room with live music.  The sound wasn't bad back there, def had a VFW vibe.

More geeky hipster guys, but thats ok because they are generally afraid of women.

Cool upstairs balcony to point and laugh from.
author: Peter H.

description:
Is it wrong to like going out in the 'loin just so you can watch hookers run from the cops?  Actually, if I have to ask, it probably is.  Forget I said that.

Edinburgh Castle is, surprisingly, not an actual castle.  I know, disappointing, right?  However, the lighting is appropriately dark, the drinks are appropriately strong, and the booths are appropriately sticky.  Just try to remember not to wear the fishnet/stilleto combination if you're headed here...
author: Jess T.

description:
Fantastic - GREAT jukebox and decent beer/food.  Their speciality, the fish and chips, was decent, just like home (Scotland) BUT portions small (or maybe I've just been in America too long!) so go for the 3 piece.  Not been on Fri/Sat nights just Sunday evening which was relatively quiet, but the barman, a nice unassuming Irish guy with grey hair, tells me it's 'mental' so I guess I'll just have to check it out.
Watch out for the amusing caber tossing / highland games pictures on the walls.
Oh yeah, it's in a BAD ASS area of town.
author: A H.

description:
This is a really great place to enjoy a pint, especially on a rainy day. The cavernous, dark vibe really helps, as well as the jukebox. They need a little more Belle and Sebastian on it maybe. The pub food is more than passable if you attack it with the beer munchies.

Minor downside: the place has become a popular date spot  for Anglophile couples....who will actually share a (single) pint!?! I mean literally share ONE. What?
author: Jim Z.

description:
Best Pub Quiz in the City. Best bartender in a non-bantering role. Great selection of single malt scotch and draft beer. The Old Chelsea link is quaint, they even serve the fish n chips wrapped in newspaper, too bad it can't be the Sun. Note: the fish n' chips are NOT good. They don't even try. But after a few beers you could drop an old shoe in hot oil and slather it in salt and vinegar, it'd taste pretty good.
They used to have the worst cocktail waitress in the City but I think she quit.

Update: I've decided that the non-bantering bartender has to be  Alan Black, author and blogger. So you know he has things to say -- just not to *me.*
author: jim b.

description:
I went here for the first time Sunday night with the volunteer training crew from Shanti. We'd just spent a long, intense weekend teaching peer counseling skills to a bunch of new recruits, and we needed to relax. This was an excellent place to do it.

It wasn't crowded, but it was also Superbowl Sunday, so I am not sure how normal the circumstances were. It was very low key, on the dark side like a pub ought to be, and the jukebox had a great range of music, from the Pixies to the Clash to old school Dolly Parton. Their beer on tap is limited in selection (5 or 6 different beers) but the beers they serve are good.

We didn't order any food, but they had a whole menu of fish and chips and assorted greasy salty things that go great with beer. Also a pool table in the back.
author: Angie R.

description:
Okay, so I've been here on a few occasions, and I've always had fun!

Last night I came and met up with some of my girls.  We were having a chill drinking night, none of that crazy stuff.  

They played half of Weezer's Pinkerton album, which is why I'm giving this place 4 stars and not the 3 that I think it deserves.

We were there somewhat  early, before anybody else was there actually.  Suddenly I smell IT...vinegar!  I cannot stand vinegar, and the stench was all over the place!  Yes, yes I know it's a pub.  So what!  Somebody was eating fish and chips, which I'm sure they enjoyed.  But the circulation in this place was terrible and I thought I  was going to puke into my black velvet.

Anways...fun bar, nice bartenders, somewhat clean bathroom, good music.

I just hope the next time I come they'll keep the vinegar to a minimum.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
The castle is the first bar in SF that I'd ever been to, now it's the first place I bring my friends from out of town.

Plenty of room (unless you show up late on a friday/saturday night), chill atmosphere, dim lighting, pool table, darts, bar seating and booths... it's the perfect dive.

One day, I'm going to reenact a battle scene on a table top with the colonial action figures from the display boxes above the booths. It's going down, soldier!
author: Anne Marie S.

description: Hipster central. But thats fine with me. Because Edinburgh, you help my need to get drunk and my need to save some dolla dolla bills in my wallet with your drink specials and you get me grooving and shaking with your 1964 events. Solid.
author: Amanda S.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised by the interior when I strolled in last night, for the first time. 
There weren't a ton of people in there, I easily found my spot at the bar. But there were enough people so that it didn't feel vacant and boring. 

I can say I feel totally comfortable going there by myself and knowing I won't be bored. 

Everyone was super friendly, and I didn't see any hipsters 
***thank god***

It turned out that all the people I ended up talking to had been on the same barcrawl I had been on, but at the other bars these people weren't as friendly and outgoing. 

Witnessed a little testosterone flare over the solo pool table. Ehhh, what can you do but sit back and laugh at stupid drunk boys.
author: Towanda S.

description:
While I really want to like this place, I can't get past the smell. It  stinks like really potent cheese, and sometimes the beer I've gotten on tap seems kind of warm-ish, which makes it a little hard to swallow along with the smell.

That aside, the atmosphere is awesome. There are lots of wooden booths you can sit at, upstairs and downstairs, plus great lighting, a sort of balcony-like setup so the space is pretty wide open, and there's an area to see live music. 

If they would only open the windows a little and let some of the hot, stinky air out I'd go more often! I prefer the Ha-Ra down the street.
author: Heidi G.

description:
Fun little bar in the TL / Tenderknob area. I tend to compare them in my head with Hemlock since they are both close by and tend to host eccentric bands and have booze. 

I have to give the nod to Edinburgh though cause the shows are way cheaper, there is room to move around and the crowd isn't completely oozing hipster sleaze attitude! Good beer selection, fish & chips available till 11pm served UK style in a newspaper & the pizza joint next door is one of my favorites in SF! The only 2 complaints are the dart board is so hard that maybe 1 out of 3 darts will stick and there is always a weird smell when you first walk in. Of course all this is really meaningless after a couple of beers to the head.
author: Nick V.

description:
Funny thought: unlike Irish theme pubs, there is one thing that a Scottish theme pub stands apart in. Scots are embarrassed to be seen in a theme pub... and one that harks back to home... rather than the alcohol fuelled camaraderie seen in Irish bars, the first time I came here there was almost a hint of shame about the Scots drinking their pints in here. 

"eh... yeah, ah'm only stopping in oan the wey hame fey work likes... I'd go somewhere else but this is oan the wey ken?"

I am still trying to get my head around the concept of a Scottish theme pub. Thankfully these are not as prolific as the quintessential Irish bar. Still, the same rule applies : Scottish theme bar findeth Scottish people inside. That would also now include me. I always feel pressure that I am not Scottish enough, having left when I was 17 and not having that stick of patriotism that inspires so many. Don't get me wrong - I get bleary eyed when I hear a tune from the old country and get excited about any reference made to home... otherwise you wouldn't find me in a Scottish bar hoping to hear some familiar inflections. It's like an aural hug. 

Trivia night was good - I love me a good pub quiz so that and some fish and chips (haven't had any better in the bay area... not that that actually says much)... but need some broon sauce... it's just not the same otherwise. Sorry folks but I won't hold that against you - I was spoiled as  a child. 

I'll go back too - I like the booths on the 2nd floor and the fact it hasn't been uber crowded on the occasions I have had the chance to visit.
author: Catriona C.

description:
I have a Snakes on a Plane messenger bag. It is my pride and joy, and it serves a very important purpose. The Snakes on a Bag acts as a filtering process. If someone recognizes and likes the bag, I know we'll get along just fine. This is the type of place where while waiting for a beer the bag sparks conversation. That does me just fine.

Trouble is with any popular place, it's bound to get crowded. It draws a little of the hipper-than-thou scene but there are plenty of diamonds in that  rough, meaning some genuinely kick ass people to drink with. I just wish there were a few less of them so I could get my beer faster.
author: Keith M.

description:
This bar stinks. It stinks like fish, fries, vinegar, and beer.

That's because that's what they serve best! I love being able to get my drink on and dinner on at the same place. Cheap, strong drinks--if you've read my other reviews, you know that's how I like 'em.

During the week it's not that crowded so you'll get your order of fish and chips pretty quickly. On the weekends, you might have to wait up to an hour! Better put the order in before you get hungry!

This is a PUB. I'd stick to the beer and simple drinks. A friend ordered a cosmo once and it just didn't look right. It's not my favorite bar but for some reason, we always end up here at some point in the night.

Minus a star because my friend got her purse stolen here. They try to keep them out but sometimes bad people sneak in from the sketchy neighborhood so keep an eye on your valuables! You're in the TL after all.
author: Cindy P.

description:
I love the castle! Not only do they have a wide selection of domestic and import beers, they have all sorts of scotches and you can order fish and chips! 
Yeah, the food comes from the Old Chelsea around the corner, but that's half the fun, waiting for the aproned delivery people carrying their boxes of newspaper wrapped steamy goodness.
The Castle has bands upstairs, pub quiz night, and hosts many literary events.
They even have their own publishing company!
Great jukebox and comfortable booths where your group can hang out while you wait for a show at the Great American. Also a good meeting spot if you plan to hang out on Polk Street for the night.
author: Rachel M.

description:
Can't believe I haven't been back here in years! Finally stepped inside for a quick drink on a Friday night and absolutely loved the trip back mem'ry lane.

Great vibe. Just like I remember it being. Crowd has gotten a wee bit more goth. Not complaining. Just an observation. DJ spun mostly goodies. LOVE THAT.

Great beers on tap, but better yet? A nice selection of scotches. Not too shabby for a Scottish pub. ;-D

Bummed that I came in too late to order the fish and chips, so I had to run next door for a quick garlic french fry fix.
author: BrasilPo P.

description:
I love this place. It's the bar where someone accused my husband for "faking his Scottish accent". Hubby and I nearly fell off our stools from laughing so hard. Glasgow, Scotland, is from where he hails and that man should have counted himself lucky he didn't receive a Glasgow kiss. ;)

I'm not much of a drinker, but hubby loved this bar because it reminded him of home along with the fish and chips...which, btw, can be purchased around the corner from the fish and chip shop that is owned by the same people who own the Edinburgh Castle.

They still remember us...even after ten years.

...and it never fails, I feel like I am sitting right in the heart of an embarrassing family moment when the mama hen bartender looks right at us and goes, "Ten years and no kids yet?"

Maybe we *don't* want them remembering us...
author: Carina M.

description:
We went last Tuesday, and had the pleasure of entering the trivia contest. Prizes all around, and free to enter. This place is moderately hipster, but not overly hipster, for us non-hipster people.

Decent selection of beer. Pitchers were $13.50, not too bad. The fish and chips were amazing (maybe because we were drunk?), but took about 45 minutes to receive.

We didn't care about sitting at a booth, but with our fish and chips, it would have been nice. Unfortunately, we didn't see any open up when we were there. A spot at the bar did the trick.

The smoking room worked wonders, as it kept the smell away from the rest of the bar.
author: Gary S.

description:
I like this spot quite a bit despite some downfalls. It's in a little bit of a shitty area (about three blocks from my house actually), I usually try to stay away from this area late at night but the castle manages to bring me around quite a bit as they have some cool free shows (although the sound presure level in the live room can be a little high with it being as small as it is) in addition to some other amenities. 

Pool table, darts, etc. for those that like to get their game on. 

Usually a pretty cool atmosphere. Vibe is pretty casual, people are generally friendly from my experience. It can get a little bit crowded on weekends but hey it's a cool spot and people know it so what do you expect.

They have castle quiz nights and other stuff like that which you can go scope out on there online calendar as well. Something for everyone at the castle!!
author: Tommy P.

description: Opps I think I was in another Castle Bar, not Edinburgh Castle Pub.
author: Steve A.

description:
Maybe it's the fact that I live so close and I'm already pretty tanked up when I hit this spot on the borderlands of the nice and not so nice, but I always manage to have a good time at this place. The decour gives off the medieval style, one of the only if not only place in town that does. 
There's nothing real special about the drink selection or the prices, but their 60's night has always had a certain charm to it. It really gets people on the floor and you hear music you otherwise would not. They also take requests so if you have a certain 60's jam on your mind, please indulge. 
The crowd is usual mission hipness, so if that's your thing, swing it!
author: Tosh J.

description:
My first and only experience at the Edinburgh was attending the Rabbie Burns Birthday celebration there a few weeks ago.  I arrived early to stake a place for me and buddies, who in turn arrived later.  Ended up on the mezzanine level, after taking up my Belhaven ale (peet smoked, excellent, recommended) and snagging a small booth.

It was a Saturday night, but a special event, and I'm guessing (though I may be wrong) that there were tables that were usually there that were moved for the event (which involved piping in the haggis and such), severely limiting seating.  Annoying.  

One of my buddies arrived a while after I was seated and working on my second Belhaven, and we ordered fish and chips for each of us.  It took about an hour and a half to get our food!  Damn.  But it was good, even accounting for the fact it was partially seasoned with hunger.

The place is a dive, no doubt.  I may head down there sometime when theres's not a special event and check it out.  Oh, and don't park on the street out there: pay the 10 bucks and park your car in a monitored private lot;  there are at least a couple on the street within a block or so.
author: Russell W.

description: To really be honest here, you guys are going to pay a fat cover for music that's going to play at any other bar. And on top of that the drinks are incredibly expensive. We found the people working at the bar to be rude and abrasive and a lot of people left around midnight because they didn't think it was worth it. If you guys want to have a good night in the city don't come here. If you come to the tenderloin to check out the place, I will guarantee you will not have a good night. My friend was visiting from Germany and we ended up stuck at this pub because there is nothing else to do in this sketchy part of town.
author: Sadia A.

description:
The Castle is always a stop on my city travels.  Tons and tons of fresh beer on tap including Fat Tire, dim and relaxed atmosphere, and the Best Jukebox in the Bay Area.  This place is spacious and has a pool table and a kind of *secret room* upstairs where live acts play.
Happy Hour isn't really that happy price-wise, but coming early sure does make parking easier.
author: Jenn M.

description:
My friend wanted to go out this past Friday night for Dresses, Drinks and Dancing.  I had to totally flake out on the dresses part because 1.) It was effing cold and 2) I was going to see another friend of mine play at Edinburgh castle before meeting her

Thank goodness I flaked on the dress because I would have stuck out like a sore thumb.  And I don't think it would have been smart to walk around in a dress in the middle of the Tenderloin.

The place was pretty cool but it's not my crowd.  The cool part was, though, that they had this upstairs room that hosted the bands' performances. From the outside, you couldn't tell that this bar was big but once we walked in, it was pretty darn huge. 

Will I go back?  Hmm..maybe. If i was dressed way way down and I was with a bunch of people that fit into the crowd there.  That way I can try to camoflauge myself through their presence.
author: Anne M.

description:
feels like a classic SF bar.  looks divier from the outside.  inside, balcony level, sticky floors, band in the back playing retro, eclectic crowd (to keep in perspective--i'm more a fan of ultralounge), generous/larger drinks, music played a bit too loud (hard to talk), didn't get much of a castle vibe.  easy walk from Osha
juke box music, warm upstairs, low key, full bar, beer choice
author: Rob C.

description:
Was a very unique place.  Probably would have never walked in the door if my friend Sean would have recommended it.

My first thought walking in was "Wow, it's dark in here."  My eyes adjusted.

They have a solid beer list, which is a plus.

Their signature fish and chips was cool.  It was served wrapped in newspaper, which was interesting.

Over all it was chill.  I could def see me going back.
author: Justin T.

description: I fell down the stairs once at Edinburgh Castle.  People were nice to me about it, so they get 4 stars.  I can't figure out why I won't give them 5 stars because the fish and chips are my favorite in the city, ok its not officially their fish and chips but you know what I mean.  The drinks are decently priced, maybe its the cover, I have issues with any bar/non-club in San Francisco charging a cover, but its usually only in effect when a band is on.  I don't know. I do like the set-up, the room in the back for bands, the pool table on Sundays when you can actually play and the high ceiling.  Yep, it must be the cover, maybe the crowd, sometimes I don't feel cool enough to be in there on the weekends.  Whatever, Edinburgh is def worth 4 stars, maybe 4.5 so go in and get your pub on.
author: Kristin Marie S.

description:
Best thing to do in the Tenderloin, if you're not into hookers and crack. Local legend has it that when Prince Charles visited the city (in the prehistoric ages) that his security wouldn't let him come here, because they were warned about the 'loin. So he gave the stuffy jerks the slip and came anyway, for a pint and some darts.

I don't care if it's true or not. The haven't-ever-been-washed wobbly tables, Old Chelsea fish and chips and well poured black&tans make this place well worth the trip. Just put your wallet in your jacket pocket on the way out, and don't look at the guys on the street who look like they want to talk to you. They don't. They want to take your money, because you're a blond suburban kid, despite what your tapered-jean clad hipster friends tell you.
author: Alex C.

description:
Every April, I stop drinking for a month (partly to live past 40 and partly to give myself free reign to go bananas the rest of the year). 

If you're ever doing something like this, stay away from the Edinburgh!! This place makes me want to drink a LOT. The feel, the smell, the darkness, the dank. It all adds up to one of the best, friendliest, most perfect bar experiences in the entire country!
author: Andrew L.

description:
I digs this place for a few reasons: 
a. predominantly britpop jukebox
b. spacious place to booze
c. memories of good 'ol Scotland!
author: Marcia F.

description:
I'm sure there are already a ton of review talking about how awesome dance parties go down here, so I'll just briefly agree :) . Really, though, you should stop by edinberg sometime for a few drinks in the afternoon or early evening, or on a night without the DJ's, because their juke box is the reason I'll return again and again to this rad pub.

The jukebox is kind of hard to figure out at first, because the list doesn't seem that comprehensive... that's because by default it just shows you a bunch of top of the charts junk, but if you click on search you can find just about any song you should be allowed to force others to listen to. I'm a punk but had no problem finding all my favorites. The catch: the more rare tracks cost you two credits instead of one (aka 1 dollar). 

Edinberg also has the best selection of beer in the area to my knowledge (And I live two blocks away! And I'm an alcoholic!). There's one bartender that's not so good there, but the rest make delicious mixed drinks. The staff are interesting and nice. There are also tables, and cocktail waitresses to come around and take care of your next round without you having to stand up, which in some birthday or celebratory scenarios is a big plus. There is a smoking room so you don't have to freeze to death to get your nicotine fix. I wouldn't exactly call Edinberg a pub except that I'm pretty sure the English bartender owns it... its kind of just a big, nice, wooden bar.  

Three cheers and five stars for this rad bar!
author: Alexander W.

description:
Yes, it is a dive and that is what is so very fabulous about it. People are there to drink and be with their friends and that is all. It is so nice to be in place where you do not have to get your ass grabbed all the time. When I go here with my friends I tend to get drunk, loud, maybe dance around like a fool; nobody even glances my way because they are just there to chill...I love that.
The fish 'n' chips are great too and the smell of vinegar is actually a good thing if you are a homesick Brit.
author: Lilly O.

description: Nice place to chill/dance/drink on a Friday night. Heard the trivia night is good too.
author: Shannon B.

description:
Why is the main Yelp picture of the Edinburgh taken during the day? It looks so weird all lit up and not blurred by a gallon of whiskey. 

Get a booth with a bunch of friends and enjoy, Just don't let the birthday boy pee on people in his own party while sitting at the tables in the corner near the door.

"Don't worry, he was wearing a pee coat" only cuts it on your birthday homie.
author: Big W.

description:
I like this spot, its kinda smelly, dirty, but they fit right in to the neighborhood.
I think its the only place in SF where I can drink a real Fullers.
author: Tom S.

description:
Fraidy-Cats! 

Back when I was super-hot (and stupid, and young) I used to walk to this place from Northbeach in fish net thigh-highs and my favorite 1970's fur mini-skirt.  Traversing the Tenderloin is all about ones attitude, or maybe better advice might be: When in the tenderloin, dress and act like you belong there. No, that's not right either...pretend that you own it and that you may or may not be packing.

Yeah, that's better.

This place was always a hoot and full of oh-so-many euro-trash wanna be rockstar types that I'd call in all my girlfriends and we'd still have plenty to choose from. Made the mistake once of dating one and got caught putting the moves on his roommate (I mean come on! The odds?!?! They all look the frikkin' same, especially after 8-9 shots of tequila and god knows how many Anchor backs.)

But I digress; This place will get you f$#cked up, let you smoke out the back door, and go and get you fish-n-chips about the same time you decide, "Any more and I am gonna hurl."

God Bless 'em.
author: Genevra P.

description:
I wasn't really in the mood for an Irish pub when my friend dragged us here, but I was pleasantly surprised that Edinburgh's is no typical SF Irish bar, but a cool, laidback, young people hangout in a convenient location. When we first walked up to the door, the "bouncer" was a little preppy Indian guy playing on his iPhone. We confusedly handed him our IDs wondering, "is he just pretending to be the bouncer?" After he engaged us in a quick friendly chat, we sidled into the mostly empty bar and occupied one of the cool booths on the side. I think we were too late for happy hour but the drinks were pretty cheap anyway - like $2.50 for PBR on tap. They also have an upstairs balcony area, a free jukebox, and a pool table. And I can't get enough of their fish'n'chips delivery service and super-friendly staff! The "waiter" (another young guy who didn't look the part) kept politely asking if we needed more drinks and he promptly took our fish'n'chips order and brought it over to us along with some sauces. It was wrapped in greasy newspaper and everything. 

Great place to hang out, especially during the week.
author: Alexander M.

description:
This is a good place to bring people from out of town when they visit, so as to trick them into thinking I hang out at cool places like this and have a life.  Both of those statements are mild exaggerations.

I like it that they serve the Black Prince Porter here.  Also, if you go on rocknroll dance party night, which I think is Wednesdays, there's plenty of foxy wimmins shakin' it loose.
author: Gopal R.

description: I told people that I was "drunk at a castle" and everyone managed to find me...sweet. A great Friday night crowd and a nice whisky selection. '90s music night is totally tits.
author: Alex H.

description:
care for a pint? This is my second favorite place to get a pint and chips in the city. Its dark and moody, with plenty of table seating. Order your food right away and it will arrive wrapped in newspaper. If there was smoking- I would totally be transported!
PS dont forget to take your coat to the loo, its effing freezing in there :~
author: Melissa B.

description:
I came here to listen to my friend Ryan read from his amazing book Kung Fu High School. I'm impressed with any bar that is doing literary readings in strange attic rooms. 

Afterward a large group of us grabbed a booth, caught up, and had a great time. They have a fun jukebox and lots of space to move around and mingle. 

It's not out of this world, but the fact that they support the literary scene is five stars alone.
author: Dixon T.

description: The decor is quaint, staff is friendly, and most importantly they have a wide selection of craft beers. I usually come here for their 80's night on the second and fourth thursdays. Best place to hear alternative music from the 80's and sometimes a little dance party breaks out. It's lots of fun.
author: varuka c.

description:
The other night with Anne. 

Some man in short sleeves, elbows on those sticky Edinburgh tables said, he appreciates a girl who insists on buying their drink. 

I'm waiting for: not this man. But another. He'll buy, even if I say no the first time. That's the tricky thing. And he'll probably appreciate books I like. Still be a man, like my high heels, watch the game with me. To take walks with, and Charlie.  

Anne said, wear an advertisement saying so pinned to my cardigan.
That'd make it a guarantee.
author: Jenny T.

description: I've only been here once, and it was probably before a show at GAMH. It's not bad, it's not great, but somewhere in between. Kinda chill, kinda mellow. I remember someone brought a dog in - it was seating on one of the bar stools near us, all human like. I don't think it was drinking. My sister's late Golden Retriever would have been drinking beer, that dog loved beer, you had to be careful or he'd jump and lap it up right out of your glass or lick your beer bottle. Yeah, I know, weird segue: non sequitur.
author: Ken L.

description:
Back in the day when I was drinking a lot more, this used to be my spot. I still love it, they have an amazing selection of beer, and the cocktails are always stiff. Oooh, and the fish and chips, a perfect addition to your beer!

 I would recommend going early on the weekend before the hoards of hispters show up, it's usually pretty mellow during the week.
author: Kelly L.

description: I went during a weekend afternoon.  There were only 2-3 other people in the whole place.  It was quiet and dark, but pretty interesting once your eyes adjusted and you took a look around.  (BTW, quiet and not crowded are definitely qualities I look for in a bar so these were big positives for me)  They had some great scotches, whiskeys, bourbons and the like (not my cup of tea, but others in our party really enjoyed them).  We had just eaten the last time I went in, but I'm excited to go back and try their fish and chips.  Someone else at the next table ordered them and the smell tortured us the whole time we were there.
author: Amanda R.

description:
As far as this bar goes, I want to love it.
They have a great selection of beers on tap, lots of seating, a wonderful smoking room, fun vibe, it's close to home...
One thing that perturbs me:
RUDE BARTENDERS!!
I have been working in the service industry for a long time, and can easily brush off a surly bartender, hell, I AM A SURLY BARTENDER!
There is a total difference between being busy and efficiently completing orders, perhaps without a smile, and being borderline abusive to customers just because you feel like it.
This has been my experience at Edinburgh for the past few visits, and although I love many things about this bar, I think my visit Friday night will be my last.
I arrived late with a buddy and my boyfriend.  We were just going to have a beer and shot before going home.  I hopped in a line to grab us the goods.  Well, for some reason, the bartender decided that my line wasn't a line anymore once I reached the counter.  I figured he would be back, as no bartender could abandon a sweet lady who finally made it up front.  He was, almost a full 15 minutes later.  I gave him my order (a pitcher and 3 shots) and he began to prepare them with without a word... no confirmation, no "ok", nothing.  After giving me the death stare upon correcting him (he made me a whiskey and soda, not 3 shots of whiskey) he tossed me a pitcher and 3 shots.  Then walked away.  No glasses, no "thanks", not even a hint of a smile.  As I sit feeling snubbed and rejected, I look down and there is a giant beer-tap booger floating on top of my pitcher.  Sick!!!! Fer real dude?  We all know that stuff is in there, but it shouldn't be floating in my beer!  GROSS!  I ended up grabbing glasses from another guy, CHUGGED EVERYTHING, and GTFO.
author: Jannea T.

description:
Oh my God, I love Edinburgh Castle!

I can't even count the number of times I've gotten stinking drunk in the darkened bowels of this, my favorite pub in all the land.  

I spend every birthday there.  One year, I tried to celebrate at another bar (at the suggestion of a friend), and ended up at the Castle anyway.  

The fish & chips from around the corner are the greasiest, most awesome thing ever.  

And since it's on Geary, all I have to do is stumble outside, and I am at the bus stop.  Then I simply wait 3 hours for the Dirty Eight to show up.  Sweet.
author: Akemi Y.

description:
Edinburgh Castle is low-lit so make sure that no one has to perform surgery on you here.  However, if you are training to be a tunnel rat or assassin it might be just the place.  The place is quite roomy but I don't think you'll get lost.  Use fluorescent bread crumbs (remember the low-lit thing I mentioned earlier?).  Ask the bartender for a handful or two.  Fish and chips:  what other type of food will ever be served to you wrapped in newspaper?  For some reason that sells me on it every time.  

The only thing I don't like about the place is the weird upstairs back room where live music is played.  I think the acoustics there suck and the place has a very cramped feel.  

As a bar, Edinburgh Castle rocks!  As a place to go if you just visited your eye doctor and got your eyes dilated and are sick of wearing those goofy sunglasses they give you afterward it also rocks!
author: Steve B.

description:
Oh hellz yes. I go here for their fish & chips alone. I've never had anything like 'em anywhere else; they're amazing. So crispy on the outside and tender on the inside. And they're even served the traditional way, in newspaper & everything!

Great beer selection too. I went with a friend who is a beer connoisseur, and this is one of his favorite places. He ordered us some Scottish beer that I'd never heard of (wish I could remember the name) and boy was it yummy. Er, hm, I just asked him and he said they don't carry it (Belhaven) or any of the amazing Scottish beers any more... Boo. But that's okay, for me the big draw is the fish & chips anyway! 

All in all the Edinburgh castle is a cool place to just go and grab a pint and have some tasty greasy pub food. I'd go there more often if it weren't on the wrong side of the bay...
author: Heather H.

description:
They used to have the best Jukebox in the city.  New Wave, Old School Ska, a little of everything you might want to hear.  It even had Taco's version of Puttin on the Ritz, which I used to listen to when I was seven on my Mickey Mouse radio.

Now they have an internet jukebox, which defeats the purpose of a jukebox: defining in music the feel of a bar.  You can't do that if people can find any old song they like in the tidal wave of choice that is the internets.

Please note my stern disapproval.  

Its still a good pub, got a nice feel, authors like Alan Black for bartenders,  fish and chips, pool, pinball, and darts.  If they brought the jukebox back I would give it five stars.
author: Flemm F.

description:
The best bar in San Fran.  Bring a friend, order a Guiness & Jameson, along with some of the fish & chips (authentically wrapped in newspaper) that they bus over for you from the nearby Chelsea Fish Co., grab a table and sit in the dark.  The place has a grungy literary vibe--they sell books behind the bar, Irvine Welch does readings at the Castle when he's in town, and there's a small room off the balcony where they host bands and comedians.  Toward the back are a few stairs to a mezzanine with a pool table, and then on either side of the mezzanine the stairs double back to balconies where you can sit up with the tattered medieval-type banners hanging from the ceiling & look down on the bar.  On the whole, the place has the feel of the dining room at Hearst Castle fallen on hard times.

My only reservations about this place are there's a roughly 3:1 guy:girl ratio on the busy nights, and the crowd can tend toward people who wear leather or ripped clothing, or otherwise put some effort into looking tough.
author: Ryan G.

description:
Ahh, the smell of vinegar and feet. Meybe it was just vinegar. But I have always thought that vinegar smelled like feet....wait this is going off track. 
I like this place. It is solid. It has lots of taps, with good beers in them. It has everykind of weird whiskey and scotch. It has a jukebox- apparently touched by the hand of god- that is so good. It has a chipper service. It has enough seating most of the time.  The wood looks like its out of the Tower of London re-creation. 
Sometimes you have to sidestep a crack ho to get in the place. But you are in the tenderloin, polk gulch area.
And sometimes there are too many "haircuts" there. 
But the place, as said before, is solid.
author: shannon t.

description:
Behold...The best bar in SF. From the moment I first stumbled into this bar I knew I was in love. The smell of fish and chips filled the room. The taps were all filled with my favorite kinds of beer. The Jukebox was obscure to say the least and ready to be bullied. The bartenders were all nice. I see stairs that lead up to a second floor. So I pass the pool table, dartboards and I make my ascent to the second floor. Wait. What's that? I hear the subtle sound of rock seeping through a tiny door. I open the tiny door to reveal... A rock band playing live in a tiny room above the bar. Awesome! Edinburgh Castle I want to make love to your face.

Now your probably wondering. "Is there anything bad about The Castle."

That's funny you should ask because there is one big problem

TOO MANY HIPSTERS!

There are more tight jeans here then at a Motley Crue concert circa' 87. I was at the jukebox and someone had put on a Miles Davis song. A very attractive hipster girl comes up to me and says, " Oh my god this is Mile Davis, I love Miles Davis. Did you put this on? Because I love Miles Davis." 

OK 

#1- I didn't put Miles Davis on. I was born in 1981 and I act accordingly.

#2- You don't like Miles Davis. You pretend to like Miles Davis because you think it will make you look cool and hip.

#3- Your not cool and hip. You come across as a condescending douche. Now wash your clothes and get your own personality.

Sorry about that rant. Anyways this place is a great bar. If you hate hipsters you might want to subtract a star. If you are a hipster you might want to add a star. If you don't know what a hipster is you might want to go to Wikipedia.

Wow this is a terrible review. Ignore everything I just said and just go to the bar. Try the Fish and Chips.
author: Barton K.

description:
Sitting around, doing nothing on a weekday night in the TL? Drag your ass out and head over to The Castle. Cheap drinks, live music, pool table, dart board, jukebox, 1964 and the hint of haggis lingering in the air. 

And we all know how we love the smell of haggis...
author: Rodney V.

description:
This place ain't so bad. Pool, darts, eclectic (and sometimes very friendly) crowd. Not TOO many hipsters...just enough to tolerate. 


I've yet to meet ONE friendly bartender though. One of the few places I'll rarely tip.
author: Ryan R.

description: Totally packed, but I don't know if it's always like that or just because of the event that was happening there.  Didn't get to try their fish and chips but saw ppl walking around with newpaper packages of them
author: Jennifer A.

description: Went here cause my boyfriend was performing.  I witnessed the newspaper meal.  Hee hee!  Overall it is a bar with tons of cool stuff here.  I like how it is constructed to feel like a tavern.  Just a thought, wish they served the drinks in those cool cups that they have hanging above the bar.
author: Michelle M.

description: Awesome place. Good prices and bar area feels like alleyway in medievil times or something. Cool feel great people
author: Chris D.

description:
5 stars for the fish n chips! Ok, so they don't actually make them here, they're 'imported' from the takeaway down the road, but it makes this place a whole lot better.


 There is also a selection of British beers and a good pool table you still know that you're in San Francisco though.
author: Alistair H.

description:
This was my second experience at the castle.  Both experiences were pleasant.  This time I ordered the one piece fish and chips with my beer.  I just couldn't resist.  It was a perfect complement to the tasty Fatlip I was imbibing and they have waitress service so you don't even have to pick your fat ass off of the booth seat to get it.

That's what I am talkin' 'bout!
author: Tracy A.

description:
Can't believe I haven't reviewed this icon.  Well I most recently was there for trivia night (Tuesday) and had a blast although I don't quite remember the entire evening.  I guess starting off with a shot of Fernet, followed by a pint of Racer 5, and a shot of Makers, and many more pints of Racer 5 didn't do my brain much good, but it was a lot of fun.

Stumbling outside and scraping up my hands made for a memorable -albeit hard to remember - evening - thank god for text messages!
author: Gene X.

description:
I consider this my regular bar.  It has a great juke box full of David Bowie, Beck, and more that I can't think of right now.  It's a great place to throw some quarters in the juke box, sit down with friends and have drunken talks about things no one really knows about, but like to think they do.  And if you are hungry order the fish and chips, but be patient. They get them from a place down the road.  Worth the wait.  

Oh and a few things that may interest some of you.  Pool tables, nightly bands upstairs, and dirty bathrooms.  Plan and simple, a good bar.
author: Alexis M.

description:
I like this place.  I hadn't been in about a year and was pleased to see that nothing has chagned.  The bathroom hasn't even been cleaned from last time!

Awesome!

That being said the beer is cold and there is plenty of room to strech out. If you have more than four people in your party then skip the crowd at Hemlock and stroll on down here.
author: Thadd L.

description:
Gosh, does this place have the cheapest pitchers of beer or what?  I think it's $8.75 for a pitcher of Pabst...which is so cheap that my boyfriend just drank right out of it (no glass needed)!  Be careful with the fish and chips, though, a friend became violently sick from them.

Trivia night on Tuesdays at 8pm are always fun with a group of friends, be sure to study the SF Chronicle beforehand!!
author: Tabatha Y.

description:
What is up with all the baseball caps who hang out here these days?  You know the type, the guys who are too old to be skateboarders, but are still into streetwear.  You can find them outside of HUF between 5 and 7 PM.  

True, I think they're all hot, but it's so weird to see them all assembled in one place!  I go into lust overdrive!  Like, get away, hot boys!  Trust me, you DON'T want to be around once I get drunk!  Not one of you will be safe!
author: Coco D.

description:
yes, it is an awesome bar. But let's skipsy straight to what really matters: the pub quiz. I have done a few pub quizzes in my day, and this one is pretty dang good. The questions are appropriately difficult but not too anything and the emcee not annoying (ETA: sometimes he is annoying).  I struggle with it though, since my 25-going-on-50 status wants me in bed by the time the answers for the last round are being read.

ETA: also, the piglet-voiced MC ALWAYS figures out how to bungle the music category. ALWAYS.
author: Shannon V.
Suo L.

description: There's something I just love about Edinburgh... perhaps it's the creepy mural at the back, or the one-of-kind look of the whole place.  Billiards, jukebox, or creep up to the mezzanine if you want to watch the crowd from above.  I hear the room at the far end of the mezzanine is sometimes open for DJs and dancing, but I've never seen it.  Lot's of great beer on tap, at reasonable prices.  Efficient service.
author: Greg W.

description:
As much as I detest traveling far-ish for a bar, I have to say that I do enjoy the Castle and am often willing to make the trek to the TL. I like the open space, the stalled bathrooms ( I have a thing about small spaces, it's not your problem so please do not worry about it), the comparably cheap beers and the casual atmosphere. Not too hipster, but not too normie, its a nice mix of people. 

There's also a smoking room, which is cool but I hate coming home reeking of smoke, seeped into my clothing and stinking up my pretty hair. 

 I guess bands play here, but I've yet to see it. My friend's played a while back and he complained about lugging equipment up large wooden stairs. Again, probably not a problem you, the patron, will run into.
author: Emily S.

description:
I can really only comment about Tuesdays...

I've been coming here for the "Castle Quiz" for over four years. It's so predictable that friends who don't play trivia have stopped by here on a Tuesday to say hi. 

Yes, the quiz is tough. Luckily (well, for me), my teammates are damn smart, so we usually do well. (Don't be mad.) I'm just there to add my two cents in the picture round. And drink lots of beer. My complaint would be that it tends to go loooong. It starts at 8:30 and usually isn't over til 11. It seems like Carl (the quizmaster) is trying new ways to make it go faster, but it's still lagging. 

They have a limited staff -- one waitress (Kim) to serve the entire place (and the quiz usually has 20+ teams), but she's on top of it. Tip her well! As for the guys behind the bar... I've never seen them crack a smile. If you want fish & chips, they are brought in from a place around the corner on Larkin. It could take a while, so if you're starving, you'd be best off just running over there between rounds and grabbing them yourself. 

If you do want to check out the quiz, be sure to get their early. Tables go fast, and if you get there at 8:25 you'll find yourself standing.

Also, if you come here on a Tuesday, but aren't there for the quiz, beware. We tend to take it pretty seriously, so if you're loudly talking at the bar while Carl is reading question, the folks around you will probably shush you. Don't get offended. Just grab an answer sheet and play along.
author: Tara B.

description: This was one of the first bars that I went to when I moved to SF.  Great place to have a pint with friends.  Only one pool table but there is usually some sort of entertainment or event on their calendar for your entertainment.
author: Patrick V.

description:
this place isnt usually the type of place id be into.
i love dive bars, but the crowd that USUALLY frequents them, not so much.
im usually the type to hit a mission "dive" bar between 8:30-9:30 before the crowd comes, then go somewhere else.
that being said,  i LOVED edinburgh. i came out on a wednesday with some friends since we all live in the neighborhood and had a great time. the crowd isnt pretentious hipster like some may think, but had the hipster style (does that even make sense? whatever)
drinks were cheap, AMAZING beer selection, they took card (which is rare for a dive), i liked the music and the people were genuinelly friendly (i dont even smoke unless i drink and i was bumming cigarettes from SOMEONE all night)
it was my first visit, which usually doesnt meritt a review. but i had enough fun i think it deserved one.
maybe it can get its 5'th star on my next one. =)
author: Ryan L.

description: Went here right after the Giants won the World Series and the place was empty!!! For such a large venue, there were only 5 people when we walked in. The bartender was nice and friendly, but it cost $6 for a pint of pear ale (yummy but overpriced). It kind of looks sketch from the inside and out, so a good idea to come here in a group and not by yourself.
author: Teresa G.

description:
I won't give many 5 star ratings to ANYTHING. (Especially people) but this bar has been so consistently comfortable and reliable, that it deserves it. Great drinks and the place doesn't smell like a dirty mop.

Tuesdays are great for Trivia. ---First date HEAVEN!

Of course, the fish and chips are divine. Good way to determine if your date is freaky about the food they eat.
author: chris m.

description:
Smells like vinegar in this joint, but it's still one of the better bars in the TL. Cheap beers, trivia night, live music, and fish & chips makes this bar very unique. 

I also like that they have a novelty machine in the men's restroom. Classy!
author: Aaron M.

description:
Oh the Edinburgh you are always an experience.

My boyfriend is in a band so that being said he has had his fair share of Edinburgh shows. Before they had a vehicle to transport their gear they would use mine putting me there around 8pm waiting for them to play a show which they say starts at 9 but really doesn't get goin till around 11.  Some of the times i have been here I have only had one beer since i had to drive all the equipment back to the Mission. However more recent times the band has found a new way to transport their goods. I get there 30 minutes early just long enough to order a few drinks and walk around socializing. They just got a new sound system going which sounds great. 

Pros 
* Only $5 to see a band
* bands play upstairs away from the rest of the bar
* very spacious 

Cons
* Parking is horrible if you are trying to park, but if you are just unloading gear you can go around the back
* That damn puddle of God only knows that i slipped and fell down on the last drunken time i was there (people laughed, it was sad)

I love this bar. I have brought my parents to this place to see my boyfriends band. My boyfriend brought his family including his grandma. People are friendly. People are dancing. It is a everyone coming together kinda place.

4 stars would have been 5 if i had not slipped on that puddle.


-------ps--------

September 28th, 2007


Better Than Aliens
Tempo No Tempo
Red Rocket
My Second Surprise

will be playing a show come check it out if you have nothing else going on!
author: Amanda M.

description:
I really enjoy this place for a number of reasons. It's local, and kinda divey, so you know that the folks here are gonna be cool. It's usually a mix-up of random people. I've seen emo kids, hipsters, punks, and business people, all merging together to grab a few drinks and hang out in the evenings.

The bar is dark, with wood all over the place. The old rickety stairs are kinda scary, but they're cool in their own way. Leading up those rickety stairs is a cool little space where I've seen some great bands playing. Usually a lot of local flavor there, and the people watching the shows are always there for the music, and not because "someone said it would be cool."

I went here once for a pub trivia night...it's kind of a joke. I mean, it's fun, but it's super loud and you can't hear the announcer and typically, it goes on for nearly forever. It's definitely something you can't do if you work early the next morning.

Overall, cool place. Drinks are decent and usual price. Sometimes hard to get a drink at the bar, but that's usual. Oh...and you can order fish and chips to be delivered there. Great on a cold evening with a nice glass of beer. :)
author: Nicolas H.

description:
I really really love the beers there. It is also a really chill environment where you can play darts and some pool. The workers are really friendly too. Also I love how they order from old chelsea a block away for fish and chips. It's a really convenient service. 
The only reason I can't give this place 5 stars is because this is in the heart of the SF GHETTO and parking is tough.
author: Nir B.

description:
the bartender girl is ridiculously hot. Don't stare at her, she's too hot. And plus you  might give her a big head so i won't have a chance. oh yea

*edit: wrote this a little drunk after getting home. ignore most of it except the stars rating
author: tony b.

description: Pricey and i think this place is just very meh. I'll stop in for a drink but it's not a place I'd spend the whole night at.
author: Kalen F.

description: hmmm, I didn't know Edinburgh was in Ireland....but I think Edinburgh castle rocks!!! I've been going this local neighborhood pub for years - cool crowd, cool music, and very tasty fish/chips.  If you are tired of mission bar scene, try this place - where cool locals hangout :)
author: ji k.

description:
What a coincidence that I came here for the first time and then saw its appearance in 'So I Married an Axe Murderer' the next day!  Katelin H. also confirmed this fact.  I love it when things like that happen.  It makes me feel so.....aligned with the cosmos or something. 

We came here with a large-ish party on a Friday night and played pool during most of it.  It wasn't too crowded and the beers were tasty.  The smell was a bit disconcerting at first, primarily because I thought it was me for the first twenty minutes or so.  I'm excited to go back again.
author: Nicole A.

description:
Quiz nights don't appeal to me, so I can't comment on those nights. (I know I'm intelligent and have too much useless information in my brain without having to prove it.  Esp. while in a cider/lager haze.)

I like this bar, sorry pub, though. Those greasy fish and chips hit the spot, and the beer selection is good.  Good jukebox but it needs more trashy, glam, punk rock selections IMHO. 

As far as the service goes, it seems like everyone else I go in San Francisco: the bartenders are lame but the cocktail servers are always really cool and kick-ass chicks that are always ready with a wise-crack and comped drinks. As a former bartender/woman in the service industry and fellow sassy, kick-ass chick, it is always cool to deal with/order from these gals.

(Also, there is another reason I've come to like this place but I cannot spill because I do not need the competition. ha, ha.)

****edit 5/24****
Upgraded to 5 stars because of the kick-ass time I had last night at the '1964' party.  I had no idea what it was and when I followed the baby hipsters with the entire Urban Outfitters window display on their backs imagine my surprise at some kick-ass 60s blue-eyed soul and dance music blaring away.  As I am a dancing fool and a sucker for good music, I tore it up on that floor.  Now I know and will wear appropriate footwear next time.  And I even managed to hold down a snicker while dancing b/c, God bless 'em but, those damn hipster babies do not have one iota of rhythm in their skinny little 20 year old bodies.  But who cares?  Dance on with yo bad selves!
author: MakeUp M.

description:
We were in town on our 3rd night of a 23 night road trip. This place was near our hotel so we thought we'd go in for the "castle theme" I had read about online. Not much of a castle theme and the bar started out lame (maybe because we started drinking at around 7pm) but became awesome. Weirdos who marry underage thai girls go there, as do hobos who love potato chips. Normal people seem to be patrons as well, but they're boring. 

The bartender was nice and the waitress tried to save us from the thai child molester who didn't seem to care that we told him we were going to murder him that evening. 

I think the drinks were cheap. And there was an amazing slice of pizza next door. This place is awesome. 

Oh and the booths there are so comfortable.
author: Katie P.

description:
I actually kind of like this place. I don't think I'd say Edinburgh Castle is in Nob Hill though - isn't it directly in the heart of the TL? Anyway, it's environs are pretty ghetto(fabulous).

The music venue upstairs is totally tiny and can get really hot. I was lucky enough to be there when a brawl broke out, but security and/or hero concert-goers got the guys out of there really fast. 

I'd go back!
author: Ava S.

description:
I never really liked this place.

Its expensive, first of all ($3.50 for a fucking PBR?!?) and it draws a holier than thou hipster crowd looking for a quick hookup. 

Cool bands play there but I feel like nobody goes there for the music. Its this nerdy pick up scene that I feel very awkward in. 

Bleh.
author: Keila E.

description:
SF Food Inspection Score: 95

I am definitely a fan of this spot minus the location and parking. 

But the service, atmosphere, and people are all enjoyable.

I do really wanna get some food next time. Malt vinegar filled the air last night (not Jen S.'s favorite thing...). Fish and chips anyone?
author: Kristina C.

description: Edinburgh Castle has the best juke box in the city.  They've got a wall full of single malt whiskey.  They will bring you fish and chips to your seat.  You heard me.  There's plenty of space and a great selection of beer on tap.  If it's not crowded, you can play pool and darts at the same time.  This is probably the best bar in the city.
author: Eric L.

description:
Used to go for the Trivia all the time. Carl, the quiz master is a grumpy old man who repeats the same jokes each week. But it's funny. And their quiz is genuinely tough! This stupid group of 3 people (named something like, "2 left feet, got no rhythm") cleans up every single week. It's frustrating, especially since they are normally the only thing that foils us.

Anyway, great divey sort of bar. Endless supply of 1664 and the fish and chips they bring in is extra greasy and good. Fun bar to go to at any time. 

I've noticed more of a hipster infiltration as of late though. Nooooooo you punks! Go back to the Mission!
author: Dave S.

description: This was a fun bar with a multitude of different seating areas that would allow you the opportunity to do everything from people watching to pool playing to singing along to a piano that is located in its own smoking area. Great for groups. Fun middle ages decor.
author: Mo A.

description: Good times. Juke box is kinda bunk. Fairly priced drinks with a quick menu from a nearby spot, good times.
author: Corvus C.

description:
Never had a bad night. Straight forward watering hole with fish and chips.

With it's just intimate enough and just noisy enough ambiance, this is a great place to be with friends.
author: Therese M.

description:
Favorite bar in this city!

I used to go all the time, but lately I've been sticking closer to home.

But, seriously. I love this place, It's a meeting place for me and my old co-workers. We still meet up there every once in a while.

It gets pretty crowded on weekends. Lots of hipsters, but whatevs. I prefer going on Weeknights. More laidback. More space. And you can usually get your mitts on the pool table and juke box. 

The only drawbacks (but, pieces of the Castle puzzle that I believe are essential): it smells like vinegar, but it is because they serve fish and chips, which is pretty cool; there are oodles of hipsters... and recently they closed the upstairs area, which sucks because they had cool performances and dance parties. Bummer. 

Also, after the bar closes, go next door to Irving Street Pizza. YUMS!
author: Natalie H.

description: Mike and I came in for a couple drinks during happy hour one Monday and the place was empty. The bartender was really nice and the beers were really cheap. Cash only though. We played a game of pool ($1 per game). Mike's complaint was that the beer tasted old. The bathrooms were pretty nasty here, but that's what I expected of a dive bar.
author: Mel C.

description:
decor is kind of cool, but the music is weird.
strange playlist of classic white music like journey, transitioning into hip hop, onto pop.
drinks are alright.
it might have just been that night in particular, but i had a lot of bigger girls hit on me that night.

hm.
author: Simon C.

description: What happened to this place? What used to be considered a great old style pub with a great beer selection and a great juke box has turned into a nightclub atmosphere. The last few times I've been in there on a weekend night, it's like a DJ dance scene with the music is so loud that you cannot have a conversation...WTF??
author: L v.

description: On weekends and occasional Wednesdays, EC plays the finest 60s soul and R&B you've ever heard. Grab your girl and start dancing. Don't be shy -- others won't. This bar has generally acceptable prices for drinks and a pool table in the back if you feel like absconding to a darker space. Overall this is one of the more hipster bars in the Loin, but not so much that it totally abhors the 9-5 company types. What I mean is, it's a liberal-minded place that accepts all sorts of crowds. Anyone can have a good time here and just enjoy the atmosphere and, most important, the great music.
author: Andrew K.

description:
This is a Hipster Bar. In the Loin. 

It says it's in Nob Hill but considering it's on Geary about a block away from some of the most extreme crack heads in the city and not nearly close enough to any blondes with fake tits and bronzed skin, I would have to say this ; dive bar in the Loin. Yes, it's quite large and seemingly welcoming, with what seems to be plenty of seating as you walk in but the comfy seating is upstairs and out of the way. The bathrooms are horrendous, I've come in on one night and found one toilet literally being used regardless of it's obvious state of disrepair. Girls giggling and shitting on shit and piss and then pulling their underwear back up over their tights. Hipsters. The booze isn't bad, I don't mind a bar that serves Guinness on tap but then again, so does a few bars in the Loin.

I do remember one fond night, however, where we were surrounded by hipsters outside and my friend (wearing a kilt) decided that for true authenticity he should remove his underwear and promptly did so. In view of all the outdoor chicks and dicks (wearing girl pants tight over their junk, removing all further usage no doubt) who gaped and glared as if the mere disposal of underwear was unheard of. Just because you wear yours OUTSIDE of your clothes doesn't mean everyone has to be forced to wear them. Sometimes a little air flow goes a long way, if you get my meaning.
author: Lydia H.

description:
If I could only go here more often...alas, I'm a mama now, so I don't get out as much as pre-mama days.  I always love coming to the Castle even if it takes a shady walk down Geary after hopping off the 47 Van Ness to get here.  The beer selection is excellent and they carry great 30 year whiskey to boot.  It's a Scottish place, after all.  The fish and chips which get whisked here from (noooo, don't, keep the fantasy alive!)...are tastey, but they do force me to eventually go to their fairly dingy ladies room to wash off the grease.  

I think the first time i came here was for an Irvine Welsh reading some years back.  Great beer and a kickass jukebox keep me coming back year after year.  The literary fests are an added bonus.  As are the truly great booths and round tables that have facilitated some of the best conversations I've had.
P.S. It's true, the bar-given darts are abysmal to play with...bring your own.
author: Jina S.

description:
I have been here on several occasions.  It is a great bar to hit up before a concert at the civic center or for just a night of stellar drinks.

Their selection of beers is awesome and in addition to that they always will let you try them before you buy (think trying flavors at a gelato place, but I've only ever really tried one at a time) which comes in a glass that is bigger than a sip.  They also serve pitchers- when i'm out with my friend I heart affordable pitchers.

The jukebox is filled with great music and they have darts.  I haven't been for quiz night, but the fact they have it makes me like them even more.
author: Maria F.

description:
I like Edinburgh, though I mostly come for 1964 which is fun because they play great music, but the upstairs "dance floor" is super smokey and smells like cigarettes and BO all heated up and evenly dispersed through the room. I've learned polyester is a bad choice of fabric to wear if I don't plan on bringing their lovely potpourie home with me.

 Anyways, drinks are reasonable, I don't mind the crowd for the most part. Every time I have been I have had a good time. 
Definitley minus a star for the stench.
author: Sarah B.

description:
If youre into hipster hangouts, enjoying doing lines of coke in the bathroom, seeing greasy hair and fixed gear bicycles, and listening to the same twenty or so 80's hits from the Cure, Smiths, Madonna...then this place is for you.

For the rest of us who are not living in hispterville you may want to avoid this place. Sure, it was cool back in 2003, but things have changed unfortunately. 

I give it 2 stars for the beer, and the jukebox. Maybe in a post apocalyptic hipster future I can see myself hanging out here, but until then I would rather go drink the same beer a few blocks away at a vast array of other great TL bars.
author: Vilen G.

description:
I told Frank eventually I'd get around to this review, but I've never had the time to fully log into Yelp and get around to it. Last time I saw Frank, I was  with two Texans and we (being me and Frank) were trying to convince them about just how big Yelp was in San Francisco. Back Ithaca ways where I am, I barely even knew about Yelp. 

But this review is not about my history on the other side of the coast; it's about the greatness that is Edinburgh. 

You see, Edinburgh sells itself to me on two principles; it's got charm, and it's not crowded full of a crowd that at most bars could be charitably described as "lively" and less politically correct given the name "preposterous morons". While some of them show up during the infamous Quiz Night, I make it my business not to, because if I wanted to be around people shouting incorrect answers, I'd go to a campus political demonstration. 

Edinburgh is perfectly located around three blocks from my apartment, and is small, and has reasonably priced drinks, and the jukebox is killer. There's all the Joy Division and The Jam and weird obscure funk tunes from the seventies anyone could want, depending on mood. 

Plus, Frank is probably the best bartender who I've known in all my days. I'm only twenty-three, but I've cruised enough bars and spent my fair share in the trenches of alcoholism to know a good bartender, and Frank is bad ass. In between a sharp with and tons of amusing stories about knocking head in his years as a bouncer, he makes a mean screwdriver and actually gives a rat's ass if you like the bar, rather than just throwing a drink at you and scowling over a pile of sorted napkins. He certainly improves upon the experience of Edinburgh. 

The other part I enjoy about Edinburgh other than location, price, and bad ass jukebox, is how easy it is to bring friends there. Some bars, you have to introduce, you have to say "this is such and such a place, you gotta understand the kind of people who hang out here". Edinburgh is the least pretentious bar I've seen, and for the west coast, that there is an accomplishment. 

Since coming to San Francisco and having been dragged too and fro all across drinking holes by all manner of malcontent, I can say that Edinburgh is easily my favorite out of all of them.
author: Daniel V.

description:
Good place to chill out earlier in the night before the real party begins.  Go any later and you'll be stuck in a crowd.  I love meeting all my buddies here for a drink first.

Or afterwork is good too, it's never too crowded then.  But I mean, this place is a bar, not a night spot...I wouldn't hangout here on a Friday or Saturday night till 2am....got better things to do.
author: Remi M.

description:
Fun place-- internet jukebox, darts, pool, great beer selection.  We may have been on an off night or something.  I have very low expectations for a dive bar, but honestly last night even I was disappointed.  Because of the beer selection and good space, I'll probably go back but I thought I'd highlight some disappointments in order to set the bar lower:

--Fish and chips and onion rings-- probably the worst I've ever had.  Flavorless, oil tasted very old!  Its been 12 hours since I ate it and I'm still sick.  I mean its deep fried.  By default its supposed to taste good.  How this was screwed up this bad I have no idea. AVOID THESE!!!

--My friend's beer-- Radeburger-- was flat (bartender apologized though and poured another-- great guy)

--DJs played old skool 45s (think 50s music).  It just didn't seem to be a good background for a rather heated darts game.

--Minor, but annoying when you are trying to kick someone's ass blind in a game-- Darts not sharp, hard to read the dart board
author: Larissa W.

description:
MMM.... fried oysters and "chips." When I first ordered the fried oysters and "chips," I thought they were real chips ha! I was mistaken- they are fries.
Even though the oysters are brought from across the street I give mad props to any bar that serves fried oysters. YUUMMYYY

I enjoy the dark pub atmosphere, the dart board, pool table and upstairs seating. I especially enjoy spying on the people below from the deck above. 

This is one of my favorite bars in San Francisco I think. There are a lot of beers of tap to choose from.

Mostly I go for the oysters though; they remind me of my moms fried oysters from the hood Canal.
author: Emilie B.

description:
Oh, the Castle...previously my favorite stomping grounds!

Fullers ESB on tap, Misfits on the jukebox, cool ass bartenders....oh way to greasy fish and chips but if your drunk enough, you will eat them and be burping grease all night, forget about getting any sleep after that so might as well hit up a store by 2 am on your way home and buy more beer to last until you've finally got more alcohol than blood in your veins!

FYI, the old guy doesn't like it if you play with the lamps at the bar, he'll leave you in darkness if you continue to fiddle.
author: Tammie C.

description:
Edinburgh castle is a great pub with good selection of beer. Coming from Scotland the Belhaven beer tastes just like home, same with the excellent fish and chips they serve! Try that for a combo, I recommend it. Great atmosphere on Fri/Sat nights and have good bands playing upstairs.

BTW Edinbugh is the capital of Scotland, not Ireland.
author: darren c.

description:
Oh Edinburgh's....what can I say about the bar that's just around the corner?  Well, for starters I really like your bartenders, and your 1964 d.j.s are often excellent.  When I came in yesterday, there were four guys playing traditional tunes and singing in the corner by the jukebox.  That does not happen at just any bar.  You smell like a combo of fish n' chips, vinegar and stale beer.  You have a pool table.  You are dark and look ancient inside.  Your sound system kind of sucks.  

All that said, I think I like Edinburgh's best when there aren't a lot of people there and I can find a place to sit with one or two friends and enjoy a couple of drinks.
author: Margaret S.

description:
When I hear the word Edinburgh, I think of three things:
  
1. The Gifford Lectures in Natural Theology, held annually at the four major Universities of Scotland: Aberdeen, Edinburgh, Glasgow, and St. Andrews.  Past lecturers include Hannah Arendt, John Dewey, Paul Tillich, and Hilary Putnam.  Its stated purpose is to promote the study of God through the natural sciences.  Which basically means the lectures are totally fucking ineffable and full of shit.  
  
2. David Hume, empiricist, luminary of the Scottish Enlightenment, and one of Edinburgh's favorite sons.  Contrary to popular belief, Hume was NOT full of shit.  Yeah, I went there, you Kantian bitches can take your fucking Categorical Imperative and shove it up your ass.

3. A portly, bearded redhead who shaves his back and wears a tartan plaid kilt which conceals a monstrous Scottish banger in casing.

Unfortunately, none of these three things can be found in Edinburgh Castle. This shouldn't surprise you -- it didn't surprise me.  Let's face it, I'm a philistine who thinks Scotland is a nation-state on the Iberian peninsula.  And by the way: is there a reason why "Edinburgh" is pronounced Ed-in-brah?  I'm not one to generalize, but do the Scots just fucking HATE phoneticism?  Or are they simply trying to drive me crazy, like the rest of you bitches?

So you will not see Hannah Arendt drinking herself under the table.  You will not see David Hume tossing his Guinness into Bishop Berkeley's face (Idealize THIS, motherfucker!).  And, regrettably, you will not blow on any bagpipes, kilted or not.

What you WILL find at Edinburgh Castle is a charming, two-level dive with a multitude of banquettes and booths, a shrine to shoegazing author and poet of the heroin drip Irvine Welsh (Welsh?  In Edinburgh?  Sorry, my ignorance is appalling), the smoothest beer on tap (Smithwick's), and a killer jukebox that contains, among other notable albums, Screamadelica by Primal Scream and Protection by Massive Attack.  

Bands habitually play in the room upstairs.  To the Castle's credit, the cover charge for the show is collected at the entrance to the room, and not the entrance to the bar -- now that's pretty fucking righteous.

They also serve food, though your choices are restricted to standard english pub fare (fish and chips, onion rings) and in fact these deep fried delicacies are actually made at Old Chelsea, the chipper on Larkin.

If you will allow me the indecorous use of The Royal We, WE met a Pretty Male Friend and a Pretty Female Friend here for drinks. As is customary, our conversation turned ribald once the booze started flowing.  We earlier established that PFF would RATHER fellate an unwashed penis than suck on someone's toes -- don't ask me to explain this, it made no sense to me either, bitch is crazy.

Me: Okay this is interesting.  So PFF I have another question for you.  Let's say you have a foot on the one hand, and an anus on the other.  Which one would you --
PFF: [flustered] Okay! Okay!  I'd suck the foot!
PMF: Hmmm.
Me: And now why is that?
PFF: Because assholes are dirty.
PMF: [turning his head away from the table to snicker]
Me: Well have you ever had -- you know?
PFF: [shocked] Oh no!  I've never had anal sex. 
Me: Really?
PFF: Really. That's where the shit comes out, it's not meant for...
Me: For what?
PFF: ....
Me: Not meant for fucking?  Is that it PFF?  
PFF: [blushing] I'm sorry! I'm sorry!
Me: [mock indignance] UGH!  You're a fucking homophobe!  I hate you!
PMF: [laughing]
PFF: [laughing] I'm sorry -- I love you!
Me: Jeez, why couldn't you tell me you hated gay people before we became friends?
PFF: [wounded child eyes]
Me: Okay seriously, look, anal sex is PLEASURABLE.  I mean, it's a little dirty, sure, but sex is dirty anyway. 
PFF: I can't do it!
Me: Yes you can. Just make sure you've got a lot of lube.  Oh and some fingering is good too. Loosen the fucker up.
PFF: ...
Me: And if that doesn't work, find someone with a small dick.  You won't even know it's there.

Sodomy is the new black and I'm bringing it to a BAR NEAR YOU!
author: d s.

description:
you will find me here on tuesday nights completely owning your ass at pub trivia.  and i have the free drink coupons and obnoxious poor winner attitude to prove it.  you think you know from useless factoids but you have no idea.  i fucking minored in this shit.  my major?  kicking your ass in this shit.  BRING IT, BITCHES!!!!  also: i am overly tired and drunk, please to ignore me.

so cool: right now there are fire truck sirens blaring loudly on church street and my new foster dog is howling along with them...i love it!  the sirens are all, "woooooooooo" and he's all, "ra ra wa-ooooooooohhhh".  amotherfuckingdorable.
author: Laura B.

description: Definitely my fav pub-like bar.  Brings me back to my times in England and Scotland.  They usually have Boddington's on tap which makes me happy.  You can also get fish and chips wrapped in newspaper, and they have lots of Brit pop on the jukebox.  what more could you want in a bar?  great place for Brits or other Anglophiles like myself.  Less crowded than Hemlock up the street and you can usually get a booth for you and your friends upstairs or downstairs.
author: Katie M.

description: Huge & cavernous, with so many places to hide. The best on a rainy day or weeknight -  AVOID on the weekends where it turns into a hipster beauty pagaent.
author: Maria D.

description: dark, dingy, fish and chips and great beer.
author: Michael E.

description: If there is any other reason to visit Edinburgh Castle besides a healthy selection of ales, lots of stretching room for yer party, a grand staircase to the loo, friendly bartenders, and a delightful internal ambiance, its the juke box.  Yes, go for the juke box.
author: Maurice G.

description: I love this place!  It's mellow and unpretentious ... a regular hangout for me and my friends.  They often have live music.  The fact that you can order food is fantastic.  I've only tried the onion rings (my friends are vegetarians) but they were good.  They have one of the best jukeboxes in the city and Tuesday night trivia is really fun.
author: Miss Purr fec t.

description: What a great bar! I loved the wood shingled eaves, rustic charm and overall layout.  Its got a neat little upstairs mezzanine level. Will definitely be back.
author: Rick H.

description: A classic Tender Loin establishment, the beer selection is where this place truly shines. Over thirty distinct beers including a fantastic Microbrew list. If you are a beer drinker and into the darker stouts and porters, I'd say get a Moylen's kilt lifter. Five dollars for a pint and 8% by volume is one of the best bangs for your buck, and it tastes great. The over all ambiance is on the hipster side, you'll never find a lack of skinny jeans and thick glasses, but I've never had a problem there. There is an indoor smoking section so nicotine addicts wont be left out in the cold, and an upstairs area that allows for better seating. It is still very much a bar with no real dance floor or music to jam out with. They appear to take credit cards at specific times but never during prime time, so you need to rely on one of the two ATM machines they have, or go across the street. Always a fun place to relax or a hot spot to go mingle on a Friday night.
author: Alexander S.

description: I'm definitely a fan. A castle-themed bar sounds cheesy, but it is pretty delightful. The bar is really long, and from my experience the bartenders are pretty attentive.
